codascud
2016-07-07 20:54
Is there a way to create or do multiple deployment of the same contract ? I am deploying contract from filesystem of peer. @muralisr any help is appreciated..

pradeep_p_13
2016-07-08 00:48
has joined #chaincode

ashnur
2016-07-08 13:59
is it possible to run code at specific time? like I deploy some chaincode that will do something in a week?

ashnur
2016-07-08 13:59
without me having to invoke anything in a week

muralisr
2016-07-08 14:00
@ashnur there is no “timer” or “crontab” like facility today

muralisr
2016-07-08 14:00
it has been talked about before though

muralisr
2016-07-08 14:03
@codascud: there is no support for creating/deploying chaincode instances (ie, based on one chaincode). One approach could be to use state to represent instances in a single chaincode

muralisr
2016-07-08 14:04
^^^ I’m sure that occured to you as well… added it more for completeness.

ashnur
2016-07-08 14:19
thanks @muralisr

codascud
2016-07-08 17:04
Thanks @muralisr .. Curious too know why is it not supported multiple instantiation on same contract ?

codascud
2016-07-08 17:04
To build a contract that should (& must) be used between mutually exclusive parties (e.g., partyA-partyB & partyX-partyY) would mean compiling & building same contract multiple times.

codascud
2016-07-08 17:05
I know in Etherium you can deploy same contract multiple times which returns different address everytime.

im
2016-07-08 17:20
has joined #chaincode

muralisr
2016-07-08 17:39
@codascud: nothing against it. just resource constraints and prioritization.

codascud
2016-07-08 17:40
ah.. ohk… So it is in future plan.. But right now not supported... thanks so much!

muralisr
2016-07-08 17:40
It could be in future plan :slightly_smiling_face:

muralisr
2016-07-08 17:41
will also add @ghaskins has quite a few ideas in that space

muralisr
2016-07-08 17:42
certainly an area where contribution is welcome…. and a few of us can help

codascud
2016-07-08 17:51
Would def. love to! just getting hang of the ecosystem...

muralisr
2016-07-08 17:51
great! here to help

kanelai
2016-07-19 10:32
has joined #chaincode

kanelai
2016-07-19 10:33
hi

kanelai
2016-07-19 10:39
i have a question about the concept of chaincode execution. i have compiled a chaincode. as far as i know, the workflow of using a chaincode is as below: 1. write it and compile it into an executable 2. upload it somewhere and run it 3. “deploy” it (and the init function is called at this step) 4. “use” it (i can now call the invoke or query functions) i have a few questions: 1. as the binary must be put somewhere to run, how is it related to the server running the peer? for ethereum, their smart contract code is really deployed to every blockchain node in the network, because the code are interpreted to some byte code format and uploaded to the blockchain. however, for fabric, the execution is done by the chaincode executable. so it must be put to servers manually. then how can we achieve the redundancy of having multiple peers when running chaincode? 2. what does the “deploy” action actually do? it is specific to the peer i run the “deploy” action against, or it does something to the blockchain network globally? Thanks!

thirumanoj
2016-07-19 13:01
has joined #chaincode

thirumanoj
2016-07-19 13:03
i have a chaincode deployed on all the nodes as a container. Now that i have updated some logic (another version) of same chaincode.. is there a way i can remove the chaincode deployed in hyperledger and redeploy the new chaincode ??

deeflorian
2016-07-19 13:20
has joined #chaincode

deeflorian
2016-07-19 13:50
Hi! @kanelai: when you deploy a CC, you connect to a single peer (hence the core peer address parameter) that'll deploy the chaincode. Then that peer will automatically broadcast the CC as a message to the other peers. The deploy messages themselves will eventually end up getting handled in the core/container module, which will in turn launch a docker container that'll host the CC. This is done by every peer when they receive the broadcasted message -- which means there is no need to run the CC manually at all, just make the CC accessible to the first peer, and the deploy action takes care of the rest.

deeflorian
2016-07-19 13:57
@thirumanoj: you'll need to remove the docker containers that are created for your previous chaincode (I don't think it's needed, but the peers themselves might have stored some info about them -- I have a script that removes the peers and the CCs too, that'll do the trick if the chaincode removal isn't enough -- also, if your peers aren't running in docker containers, the /var/hyperledger folder's contents should be cleaned).

thirumanoj
2016-07-19 14:01
@deeflorian. Tnx for the response. My four node peers are actual process running on virtual machines. can you tell me.. what all things needs to be cleaned apart from the docker CC containers.

thirumanoj
2016-07-19 14:02
or can you share your script

deeflorian
2016-07-19 14:07
@deeflorian uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/deeflorian/F1T2TCT1N/-.txt and commented: I use this as a cleaner... The docker parts are actually documented somewhere on the wiki.

kanelai
2016-07-19 14:13
@deeflorian: oh i’m confused. recently i just have a lesson given by ibm staff, and they demonstrated how a simple CC is created and used. they first write some code base on shim. then `go build` it. what i get is a binary executable file. then i have to set `CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME` and `CORE_PEER_ADDRESS` and execute it. next we use `peer chaincode deploy` and specify the CC name using `-n` arg. so, what i get so far is, the binary that i executed is the one who actually does run the CC logic (though i do not quite understand how it relates to docker and who actually spawns the VM). and the `deploy` step is simply used to instantiate the CC instance by calling the “constructor” (i don’t know how to call it, but i think you know what i mean). all these seems not quite align with your description. could you please elaborate more?

shishirvd
2016-07-19 14:24
has joined #chaincode

deeflorian
2016-07-19 14:35
@kanelai: Ah... I'll be guessing from here on, but isn't that only used to develop and test CCs? I think actual deployment to a network of peers should be done through a `peer chaincode deploy` with a `-p` argument that specifies the binary location itself, and a `-c` argument that has the 'constructor'?

kanelai
2016-07-19 15:10
@deeflorian: you’ve made a good point! because that’s a tutorial lesson so that procedure may not be the same as that in prod. i’ll check with the teachers. thanks!

theath
2016-07-28 13:57
has joined #chaincode

theath
2016-07-28 14:07
How can an "Invoke" completion be detected without having to poll the chaincode? Can the Invoke send an event or a callback happen after completion of the invoke? Any examples? Thanks.

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:45
@theath: the short answer is, the full support is still emerging (see some of the work on “events”)

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:45
the SDK will make this largely transparent (once the support is there) by using the “completed” callback

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:45
(the callback is there today, but its not closed loop

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:46
the SDK just synthesizes the event based on a timeout, rather than a real event

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:46
but once that is fixed, you’ll have closed loop confirmation

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:49
the online doc for the SDK isnt working, but you want to look at Member.invoke() -> tx.on(“complete”, cb)

ghaskins
2016-07-28 15:49
fwiw, i am using it here: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/examples/example02/client/sdk/src/example02/hlc/user.cljs#L23

joseph
2016-07-31 16:42
Hi,

joseph
2016-07-31 16:42
What does it mean if I set chaincode confidential?

joseph
2016-07-31 16:44
If we set chaincode confidential, we will not see chaincode's log or chaincode docker?

muralisr
2016-07-31 16:46
@joseph by “chaincode confidential” I expect you mean enable “security.privacy” ?

joseph
2016-07-31 16:50
I saw it in an example

joseph
2016-07-31 16:50
var invokeRequest = { // Name (hash) required for invoke chaincodeID: testChaincodeID, // Function to trigger fcn: "assign", // Parameters for the invoke function args: ['Ferrari', bobAppCert.encode().toString('base64')], confidential: true, userCert: alicesCert };

joseph
2016-07-31 16:52
I also think it is "security.privacy = true".

muralisr
2016-07-31 16:54
ok. state is saved as encrypted on the ledger. The chaincode can manipulate the state in the clear

joseph
2016-07-31 16:56
and what else? If I set confidential = true,

joseph
2016-07-31 16:58
it look like I can not see peer's log related to chaincode deployment and chaincode docker.

muralisr
2016-07-31 17:04
You should be able to see the log AFAIK … haven’t tried with privacy enabled recently though

joseph
2016-07-31 17:05
I see.

shishirvd
2016-08-01 12:26

muralisr
2016-08-01 12:27
@shishirvd: the deploy and invoke functions are “submitted” for later asynch execution.The deploy did not work based on your error

muralisr
2016-08-01 12:28
it might be that you did the query too soon before the chaincode dpeloy was executed

muralisr
2016-08-01 12:28
or there might have been an error

muralisr
2016-08-01 12:28
peer’s logs would have the error

2016-08-01 12:29

2016-08-05 15:26

harsh
2016-08-13 09:32
One quick question to hyperledger community can the chain code talk amonst other chain code within existing blockchain … Like in Solc one contract can interface with other smart contract if yes then how …

harsh
2016-08-13 09:32
I am failing to find a good example for it

muralisr
2016-08-13 13:25
@harsh chaincode can talk to another. fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example04 and fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example05 are the examples.

synechist
2016-08-13 15:43
@harsh and @muralisr: would you not create a significant attack surface without a trustless protocol to exchange data/services/coins across chains? I mean, the two chains may speak the same language, but a node on one chain would not be able to prove to itself facts about the other chain. The security level required would, of course, depend a lot on the nature of the service.

harsh
2016-08-13 16:36
No the point is to lets say there are multiple chaincode running in one chain and interface these multiple chain codes …

synechist
2016-08-13 16:37
Oh ok. So _if_ it were an inter-chain scenario it would be problematic.

muralisr
2016-08-13 16:39
@synechist: its still the same “chain” (ledger)…. and yes, problematic if interchain

harsh
2016-08-13 16:41
Yes agree inter chain scenario would be problematic…

harsh
2016-08-13 16:42
as it would require dealing with 2 or more chains with different states at diffrent time

synechist
2016-08-13 16:47
So... what does this multi-chaincode-per-blockchain scenario imply for scalability, volume, and bloat?

synechist
2016-08-13 16:50
That is, I'm interested in whether multi-chain scenarios are something that would need to be designed for.

synechist
2016-08-13 19:13
If this is the wrong place to have these sorts of high-level discussions, let me know.

synechist
2016-08-13 19:14
Full disclosure: my interest in cross-chain interoperability is because I'm part of a project that's delivering solutions to exactly this problem.

harsh
2016-08-14 09:19
Best use case would be Decentalised exchange …

harsh
2016-08-14 09:24
However lateral use case would come up as integration would play its game …

when developing chaincode, is it enough to test it on a single noops peer or it's better to test it with enough peers to use pbft consensus and membersrvc?

mohan
2016-08-24 14:14

jake.turner
2016-08-24 14:52
has joined #chaincode

jake.turner
2016-08-24 14:54
@ashnur I don't believe it matters how many peers you use.

hgabor
2016-08-24 14:58
Now too many answers for @ashnur :-D

muralisr
2016-08-24 15:03
well, now I have to add my bit :wink: …. I develop in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode with just one peer and no docker… the turnaround for fixing bugs etc is much better.

cbf
2016-08-24 15:38
@hgabor LOL

cbf
2016-08-24 15:42
@ashnur please keep in mind that this is the peak of summer holiday season, and many of the usual suspects are either on holiday or trying to keep things going while others are… I wouldn’t take it as a slight that you aren’t getting answers immediately

cbf
2016-08-24 15:43
In answer, I would say that noops is good enough for most testing, but to ensure that you haven’t written non-deterministic chaincode, multi-node testing is likely a requirement before deploying it in anger

kell
2016-08-24 15:51
has joined #chaincode

mohan
2016-08-24 16:16
Hi, I was trying to deploy chaincode, it was working fine until now. Today, I just pulled latest docker images and started 4 peers. I was trying to deploy chaincode_example02 from one of the peers. ``` peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Function":"init", "Args": ["a","100", "b", "200"]}' Error: Non-empty JSON chaincode parameters must contain exactly 1 key: 'Args' ``` Later found that with the latest code, format was changed. Parameter "Function" was moved to "Args" array. All parameters should be base64 encoded. So, tried with the following option ``` peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c {"args":['aW5pdA==', 'YQ==', 'MTAwMA==', 'Yg==', 'MjAwMA==']} Error: Chaincode argument error: invalid character 'a' looking for beginning of object key string ``` Not sure what I am doing wrong here...

mqmatt
2016-08-25 13:27
With the very latest source, the following works for me: peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"function":"init", "args":["a", "100", "b", "200"]}'

mqmatt
2016-08-25 13:33
peer chaincode invoke -l golang -n mycc -c '{"function":"invoke","args":["a", "b", "10"]}'

mqmatt
2016-08-25 13:33
peer chaincode query -l golang -n mycc -c '{"function":"query","args":["b"]}'

mqmatt
2016-08-25 13:33
That's after pulling the latest master from git and recompiling just now.

ashnur
2016-08-25 13:35

mqmatt
2016-08-25 13:37

mohan
2016-08-25 13:52

Btw, I pulled the docker images instead of building it from source code Strange!!!! syntax @mqmatt mentioned didn't work for me. Keeps me wondering which is the actual format to be used?

ashnur

@mohan what version are you on (what images are you using)? The invocation syntax changed since v0.5

2016-08-25 14:26

mqmatt
2016-08-25 15:25
Unless the docker images are continually refreshed (or you build them yourself), I think they might lag behind the master stream on git. The commandline syntax has changed a few times in the last few days and so I suspect the changes are only just making their way through the system.

bartman250
2016-08-26 06:47
@nikileshsa - I had a lot of connection refused errors. When I looked at my docker-machine the iptables were a mess, so I deleted and recreated it. I then had the same issue with vagrant - I rebooted my mac and it sorted it.

jchenibm

matanyahu
2016-09-06 19:46
has joined #chaincode

matanyahu
2016-09-06 19:49
Can someone please explain me if there is an equivalent of "gas" (a concept of turing-completeness from Ethereum) which defines how long a given chaincode would run until it gets extinguished by VPs? I assume there is no such a thing and therefore, there are no limits to the amount of time and resources that can be used by a chaincode executed in PBFT-driven network

matanyahu
2016-09-06 19:50
If this is the case, what security measures can be possibly taken in case a malicious code is executed by a rogue party?

jcarrivick
2016-09-07 00:11
@matanyahu Not quite sure if this will answer your question but chaincode can be anything and will run indefinitely.

jcarrivick
2016-09-07 00:12
In terms of security the peers are designed to run in a trusted network with trusted users

jcarrivick
2016-09-07 00:13
of course that doesn't exclude the case of a malicious user, but that is the point of the design

sksundaram
2016-09-07 15:17
has joined #chaincode

bala.vellanki
2016-09-07 21:34
has joined #chaincode

bala.vellanki
2016-09-07 21:39
Hi, the chaincode_example02 does not recoginze the arguments passed to Init method using the REST API. Tried the following arguments as mentioned in the example as peer on my VM but was not successful.

bala.vellanki
2016-09-07 21:40
{ "jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "deploy", "params": { "type": 1, "chaincodeID":{ "name": “mycc" }, "ctorMsg": { "function":"init", "args":'["a", "100", "b", "200"]' }, "secureContext":"jim" }, "id": 1 }

bala.vellanki
2016-09-07 21:41
Any suggestions helpful. Here is the method in the code..Used Init (deployspec

bala.vellanki
2016-09-07 21:41
func (t *SimpleChaincode) Init(stub *shim.ChaincodeStub, function string, args []string) ([]byte, error) {

bgorman
2016-09-08 01:21
@bala.vellanki I think you need to remove the '' around the args value

bgorman
2016-09-08 01:22
e.g. "args":'["a", "100", "b", "200"]' --> "args":["a", "100", "b", "200"]

bgorman
2016-09-08 01:22
"args" is an array of strings

kkoiwai
2016-09-08 03:12
Hello all, I'm pretty sure that someone has already done that, but just in case, I wanted share my chaincode snippet. It'll "migrate" world state of other chaincode when deployed. It may not be production ready but will save time when you modify code and re-deploy many times. Let me know if there're better solution available, thanks, https://gist.github.com/kkoiwai/d07311d040b7be5476b50d73662e994b

kkoiwai
2016-09-08 03:13
@kkoiwai shared a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/kkoiwai/F29BS8BUL/migrate_worldstate_go.go

muralisr
2016-09-08 03:14
@kkoiwai basically call the chaincode to be upgraded and get all of its state

muralisr
2016-09-08 03:14
?

kkoiwai
2016-09-08 03:16
right

kkoiwai
2016-09-08 03:16
nothing more than that

muralisr
2016-09-08 03:17
I think that’s a pretty good way to “migrate” in the current release

muralisr
2016-09-08 03:19
this won’t work if “privacy” is on as chaicode-calling-chancode doesn’t wrk if its on

kkoiwai
2016-09-08 03:20
Thanks, I'll keep that in mind. For future we can elaborate this and maybe implement to "void" old chaincode when the migrate function is called by a new one.

muralisr
2016-09-08 03:21
and hopefully the securoty restriction will get lifted not too distant futue

muralisr
2016-09-08 03:21
future

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:38

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:39

2016-09-08 03:47

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:47
wait I see it

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:47
you have a typo

ccooper21
2016-09-08 03:47
```tcp 0 0 127.0.0.1:48005 127.0.0.1:7051 ESTABLISHED tcp6 0 0 :::7051 :::* LISTEN tcp6 0 0 127.0.0.1:7051 127.0.0.1:48005 ESTABLISHED```

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:47
`CODE` is wrong

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:48
try this `CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=127.0.0.1:7051 ./finished`

ccooper21
2016-09-08 03:48
let me check

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:48
they connected, but the chaincode doesn't have the right name

ccooper21
2016-09-08 03:51
oh yah!! progress. thanks so much! now I am getting some error about passing the wrong number of arguments, but I think the code is at least getting invoked

ccooper21
2016-09-08 03:51

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:51
no worries :slightly_smiling_face:

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:52
you just need to tweak what your Args are in the deploy command now

ccooper21
2016-09-08 03:54
yeah. the code expects 1 argument and I think I'm passing 1 so a bit mysterious

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:54
try -c '{"Function":"init", "Args": ["x"]}'

bgorman
2016-09-08 03:57
if you don't supply a Function I think your first Arg may be stripped off and used as that

ccooper21
2016-09-08 03:57
Error: Non-empty JSON chaincode parameters must contain exactly 1 key: 'Args'

kkoiwai
2016-09-08 03:59
isnt it -c '{"Args": ["x"]}' ?

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:00
I'm guessing there was a change as the docs mention specifying the function name as well. You may be on to something though that my args aren't getting passed into the function

bgorman
2016-09-08 04:00
maybe try `-c '{Args": ["init", "x"]}'

bgorman
2016-09-08 04:01
the code in my repo does not match yours...

bgorman
2016-09-08 04:01
there's been a few changes in there recently

bgorman
2016-09-08 04:03
I'm going for lunch, bbs

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:06
Awesome! That seemed to work.

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:16
One last question... I tried calling the REST API using the Chrome Postman plugin, but am getting the following error. Does the payload need to be BASE64 encoded?

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:16
```{ "jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": { "code": -32700, "message": "Parse error", "data": "Error unmarshalling chaincode request payload: illegal base64 data at input byte 0" }, "id": null }```

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:22
If anyone is interested, the answer to my question is here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39050494/hyperledger-fabric-chaincode-deployment-base64-error

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:23
Apparently each argument has to be base64 encoded. So my deploy request looks like:

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:23
```{ "jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "deploy", "params": { "type": 1, "chaincodeID":{ "name": "mycc" }, "ctorMsg": { "args":["aW5pdA==", "eA=="] } }, "id": 1 }```

bgorman
2016-09-08 04:58
@ccooper21 that is not true of the latest code in gerrit

bgorman
2016-09-08 04:58
a change went in on 24 August to revert the REST API to non-base64 encoded

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:59
oh... that is probably around the time I built my dev env

ccooper21
2016-09-08 04:59
thanks for the info

bgorman
2016-09-08 05:02
depending on how annoying you find the base64ing, you might want to rebuild your peers :slightly_smiling_face:

pushpalatha
2016-09-08 06:46
Anyone know what does this error mean? I get this when i try invoke. | 06:42:02.961 [chaincode] processStream -> ERRO 061 Got error: Failed retrieving extension.

bgorman
2016-09-08 06:55
@pushpalatha looks like a certificate or crypto problem crypto/primitives/x509.go: return nil, errors.New("Failed retrieving extension.")

bgorman
2016-09-08 06:56
// GetCriticalExtension returns a requested critical extension. It also remove it from the list // of unhandled critical extensions

bgorman
2016-09-08 06:56
don't ask me what that means :smile:

pushpalatha
2016-09-08 06:57

rajeshsubhankar
2016-09-10 17:03
With flag `--peer-chaincodedev`

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:04
then you are expected to run the chaincode yourself - 4 instances of them pointing to the addresses of the 4 peers

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:04
you can do that of course

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:05
althought I don’t see the above parameter used in the compose files above… ?

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:05
what does docker-compose-4-consensus-base.yml look like ?

rajeshsubhankar
2016-09-10 17:05
my compose-default.yaml file contains above flag

rajeshsubhankar
2016-09-10 17:06
docker-compose-4-consensus-base.yml: ```vpBase: extends: file: compose-defaults.yml service: vp environment: - CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED=true - CORE_PEER_PKI_ECA_PADDR=membersrvc0:7054 - CORE_PEER_PKI_TCA_PADDR=membersrvc0:7054 - CORE_PEER_PKI_TLSCA_PADDR=membersrvc0:7054 #- CORE_PEER_PKI_TLS_ROOTCERT_FILE=./bddtests/tlsca.cert # TODO: Currently required due to issue reading obbca configuration location - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_N=4 # The checkpoint interval in sequence numbers - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_K=2 vpBatch: extends: service: vpBase environment: - CORE_PEER_VALIDATOR_CONSENSUS_PLUGIN=noops - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_TIMEOUT_REQUEST=10s - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_MODE=batch # TODO: This is used for testing as to assure deployment goes through to block - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_BATCHSIZE=1```

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:06
and the compose-defaults.yml please

rajeshsubhankar
2016-09-10 17:07
compose-default.yml: ```vp: image: hyperledger/fabric-peer environment: - CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true #- CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=http://172.17.0.1:2375 - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock # TODO: This is currently required due to BUG in variant logic based upon log level. #- CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG # Script will wait until membersrvc is up (if it exists) before starting # $$GOPATH (double dollar) required to prevent docker-compose doing its own # substitution before the value gets to the container #command: sh -c "exec $$GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/bddtests/scripts/start-peer.sh" command: sh -c "sleep 5; peer node start --peer-chaincodedev" # Use these options if coverage desired for peers #image: hyperledger/fabric-peer-coverage #command: ./peer.test --test.coverprofile=coverage.cov node start membersrvc: image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc command: membersrvc```

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:09
so after start up and before issuing “deploy” you need to start 4 instances of the chaincode yourself

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:10
1) docker inspect <vp0’s container id>

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:10
2) get the ip address of vp0 - something like 172.17.0.2 (example)

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:12
3) start the chaincode as `CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=<vp0s ip>:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=safety_device ./<chaincodeexec>`

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:12
and likewise for the other 3 vps

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:12
you should hopefully see the chaincodes started and registered with the respective peers

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:13
then send the deploy to vp0 as before … you should see all the chaincodes initialized

rajeshsubhankar
2016-09-10 17:16
OK. Let me try. Just to clarify, starting the chaincode require because of `peer-chaincodedev` flag ?

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:19
correct

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:20
otherwise the chaincodes will be started by the peer when you do the “deploy"

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:21
the “deploy” does two things (1) if not in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode, start the chaincodes and (2) send init to the chaincodes

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:22
so in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode you still have to do the “deploy” for (2)

rajeshsubhankar
2016-09-10 17:22
got it. Thanks

muralisr
2016-09-10 17:22
sure

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:28
so this is what I did…ran the chaincode in a container (just like the peer is ran in one via docker-compose)

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:28
first I did `docker inspect | grep IPAddress` to get the IPAddress of the peer

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:28
which was 172.17.0.2

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:28
then

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:29
docker run --rm -it hyperledger/fabric-peer /bin/bash

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:29
cd examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:29
CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.2:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc ./chaincode_example02

muralisr
2016-09-11 14:30
this at least gets you one way

2016-09-11 14:57

muralisr

2016-09-11 15:00

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:06
I’m biased but I like hyperledger :slightly_smiling_face: …

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:06
can I suggest this

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:07
do developement without security (and memberservice etc) upto the point where you are going to need you chaincode to do things like roles etc

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:08
and then add member service and security to the mixture

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:08
yeah - thanks

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:08
this makes sense

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:12
sure thing. here to help!

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:13
@muralisr are you familiar with chaincode data models

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:13
I understand right now there's a key-value DB as the backbone for state

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:13
correct

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:14
the state is all managed via key value storage

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:14
so I was exploring the IBM car lease demo

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:15
and in the beginning they were storing the vehicle's history in an array

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:15
https://github.com/jpayne23/Car-Lease-Demo/blob/master/Chaincode/vehicle_log_code/vehicle_log.go

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:15
right

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:15
but then they abandoned that approach

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:16
and were looking at the transactions themselves to figure out what happened to a particular vehicle

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:16
I have not followed that example closely ...

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:17
how do you mean _transactions themselves to figure out what happened to a particular vehicle_ ?

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:18
I’m sensing some sort of “dynamic” computation … ?

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:18
the current process is that we read through every block on the blockchain to read the transactions within it. These transactions store the function call to the chaincode (e.g. create_vehicle) and the arguments passed as well as the caller. In a transfer one of the arguments is the identity of the new owner. Using this information we can build up the history of the vehicle using the function names as a guide as because we wrote the chaincode we know what the functions do in regards to the vehicle and the order of the arguments.

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:19
I see

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:19
so the application up the stack manages history instead of maintaining it in the ledger

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:22
there are likely many ways to do this

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:23
but this way does show the different access paths to the fabric

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:27
YAY

mart0nix
2016-09-11 15:27
so upgrading Docker for Mac solved my issue

muralisr
2016-09-11 15:30
great!

lorenzoasr
2016-09-11 16:29
Suppose that i'm deploying a chaincode that let authorized users to save, delete and search for specific data into the chaincode state. Without considering the actual space limitations of the node disc, may be cause problems if chaincode state size reaches an order of hundred gigabytes?

muralisr
2016-09-11 16:31
today there’s nothing to prevent from saving any amount. So yes, large data would likely cause problems

muralisr
2016-09-11 16:32
I should rephrase that … large data could cause problems and need for storing “large data sets” on the ledger would need a careful look at the the end to end application stack

2016-09-11 19:54

# http://github.com/f00bar/learn-chaincode/start ./chaincode_start.go:34: cannot use new(SimpleChaincode) (type *SimpleChaincode) as type shim.Chaincode in argument to shim.Start: *SimpleChaincode does not implement shim.Chaincode (wrong type for Init method) have Init(*shim.ChaincodeStub, string, []string) ([]byte, error) want Init(shim.ChaincodeStubInterface, string, []string) ([]byte, error)

muralisr
2016-09-11 19:56
right. that needs to be updated. Can you try changing `*shim.ChaincodeStub` with `shim.ChaincodeStubInterface` please ?

muralisr
2016-09-11 19:57
the docs have not caught up everywhere with recent changes to chaincode interface.

muralisr
2016-09-11 19:58
this particular change has to do with the ability to unit test chaincode with a beginnings of a framework for that

mart0nix
2016-09-11 19:59

muralisr
2016-09-11 20:00

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:03
noob question : how would you model the POST command from this manual: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/Setup/Chaincode-setup.md ?

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:04
through curl?

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:04
or by invoking POST directly?

muralisr
2016-09-11 20:04
curl would work

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:04
so if I want to transform this

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:04
POST localhost:7050/registrar { "enrollId": "jim", "enrollSecret": "6avZQLwcUe9b" }

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:05
then it would be curl -X POST localhost:7050/registrar

matanyahu
2016-09-11 20:05
?

muralisr
2016-09-11 20:06
I’d put the text `{ "enrollId": "jim", "enrollSecret": “6avZQLwcUe9b”}` in a file (say log.json)

muralisr
2016-09-11 20:07
and do curl -X POST -d@log.json http://localhost:7050/registrar

mohan
2016-09-12 19:52
``` func deployInternal(deployer crypto.Client, adminCert crypto.CertificateHandler) (resp *pb.Response, err error) { // Prepare the spec. The metadata includes the identity of the administrator spec := &pb.ChaincodeSpec{ Type: 1, ChaincodeID: &pb.ChaincodeID{Path: "http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/asset_management"}, //ChaincodeID: &pb.ChaincodeID{Name: chaincodeName}, CtorMsg: &pb.ChaincodeInput{Args: util.ToChaincodeArgs("init")}, Metadata: adminCert.GetCertificate(), ConfidentialityLevel: confidentialityLevel, } // First build the deployment spec cds, err := getChaincodeBytes(spec) if err != nil { return nil, fmt.Errorf("Error getting deployment spec: %s ", err) } // Now create the Transactions message and send to Peer. transaction, err := deployer.NewChaincodeDeployTransaction(cds, cds.ChaincodeSpec.ChaincodeID.Name) if err != nil { return nil, fmt.Errorf("Error deploying chaincode: %s ", err) } resp, err = processTransaction(transaction) appLogger.Debugf("resp [%s]", resp.String()) chaincodeName = cds.ChaincodeSpec.ChaincodeID.Name appLogger.Debugf("ChaincodeName [%s]", chaincodeName) return } ```

mohan
2016-09-12 19:53
^^^ From the file https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/examples/chaincode/go/asset_management/app/app_internal.go

garisingh
2016-09-12 19:53

arconederveen
2016-09-19 13:04
@mohan I was having a similar message when I tried to deploy with the rest api. Do you also see "user runs chaincode, not deploying chaincode" According to my understaning of the source deploying through the rest when in development mode is not allowed, but please correct me if I am wrong.

arconederveen
2016-09-19 13:21
@mohan what worked for me is to register the chaincode in development mode on the command line. with: CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mychaincode CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.4:7051 ./chaincode

arconederveen
2016-09-19 13:23
Than calling a deploy on the chaincode with the rest api with the appropriate init function. ````{u'id': 0, u'jsonrpc': u'2.0', u'method': u'deploy', u'params': {u'chaincodeID': {u'name': 'myreport'}, u'ctorMsg': {u'args': [u'1', u'2', u'3', u'4'], u'function': u'init'}, u'secureContext': u'jim', u'type': 1}}````

arconederveen
2016-09-19 13:25
@mohan sorry misread you are using vagrant with the peer command. I am using the docker images.

mohan
2016-09-19 13:28
@arconederveen Thanks!! I couldn't make it work from the command line. But garisingh suggested me to look into unit tests for the NODESDK. I was able to replicate them to my application and made it work.

mohan
2016-09-19 13:30
Also, I was trying to pass metadata (user certificates) during deploy and invoke, so nodesdk was a better choice to pass those data to the application.

arconederveen
2016-09-19 13:33
@mohan Ok good to hear you got it working.

@muralisr right it was the CORE_VM_ENDPOINT, it has to be `unix:///var/run/docker.sock`. `127.0.0.1:2375` is not working for linux as says in the TODO of the docs. http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Network-setup/#setting-up-a-network -> ```If you are using the native Docker for Mac or Windows, the value for CORE_VM_ENDPOINT should be set to unix:///var/run/docker.sock. [TODO] double check this. I believe that 127.0.0.1:2375 also works.```

thomas.marckx

ranjan008
2016-09-21 11:58
@muralisr can we send json string as one of the args to the chaincode

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:36
@ranjan008 is it hard to test? Technically there is no problem - just input json object quotes should be prepended with \ normally JSON libraries do it for you - parsing in and parsing out. So you'll have it as a single line string in one of the parameters, why not?

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:36
if you want to have some special characters u can base64 it.

ranjan008
2016-09-21 12:37

ranjan008
2016-09-21 12:38
while sending i am not getting any error but when i am querying for the value i am getting empty struct

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:39
log it and check what you get and see where is an error. I believe this is app related question but not generic one

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:46
@bfuentes I designed it to be agnostic to language type…but that said, the only driver that I currently have is for golang

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:46
(patches welcome!)

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:46
I would love to have java support added

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:49
long story short, theres an abstraction (https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/tree/master/src/chaintool/platforms) that can be extended to add new types

bfuentes
2016-09-21 12:53
ok. It was just the answer I wanted to hear :slightly_smiling_face: because I have a request to a future java project on that's and it was a requirement. I could help for a patch if this project is signed :smile: Thank you

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:55
maybe a bit lost here or misunderstood but currently generated zip/tar from gradle it will not be deployed? peer assembles code on it's own? So what happens when I make a deploy of java code?

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:57
i havent looked at what the java team produced, but generally speaking, the peer _must_ recompile all artifacts and generally we would want those artifacts to either be a) part of a declared ABI (e.g. “java chaincode platform version 2” or b) included with the payload

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:57
(vs allowing something like maven to pull deps into each peer

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:58
if the gradle payload meets those requirements, then its probably not far off, but I am still advocating that the packaging should be normalized

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:58
ok, so if I include some libraries - I'll have to make the peer with this libraries, right?

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:58
well, you _could_ do that, but thats not advised and thats not what I am saying

grapebaba
2016-09-21 12:58
has joined #chaincode

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:58
yeah I git you

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:58
I mean for now

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:58
(for instance, in many contexts, you wouldnt have access to all the peers

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:58
oh yes, for now thats fine

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:59
it is the only approach

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 12:59
ok in dev mode it will work as is but in prod - I believe only custom peer will work

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:59
not sure, like I said I didnt look at how the java team implemented it

ghaskins
2016-09-21 12:59
what I hope to have is something like CAR where it can be clearly defined and/or included with the chaincode

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 13:00
ok, it make sense as by the way dependencies should be included in SHA calculation

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:00
precisely

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:00
I tried to capture that in the CAR spec

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:01
though right now, I only support golang and even that isnt fully complete as the deps do not get bundled

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:01
but I plan to fix that, and would welcome platform support for java (and whatever other languages come up)

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:02
FWIW, I get around the bundling deficiency today by using go-get on the peer

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:02
so, when you use a chaintool workflow, you dont need a custom peer per se, but its also not a long term solution

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:02
long term, I need to turn off go-get and include the deps

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:03
i can see a similar path for java

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:03
(initially, it will allow a maven dep, but eventually lock it down and include deps

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:04
@bfuentes that would be awesome if you want to help

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:07
@oiakovlev not sure how much you have looked at chaintool, but right now I assume src code is in ./src and I download any deps to ./build/deps that arent already on the GOPATH

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:08
i am thinking I will use something like a go-list walk to pull direct/transitive deps from the sythensized GOPATH and include them in the package as something like ./deps

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:08
so, then the CAR would have ./src and ./deps, all of which would be in the SHA

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:09
I would also add ./deps to the synthesized GOPATH

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:09
a similar approach would work for java too, i think

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 13:09
have not dive deeply, will have to look at chaintool, maybe if have time will work on smthng for java - will ask later who is working in that team, so we have some sort of internall planning this and prev week was in the rush preparing presentation and simple app on top of HL

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:09
just CLASSPATH instead, obviously

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 13:10
so next week should be much better and hopefully will have some time to be involved

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:10
ok, sounds good

oiakovlev
2016-09-21 13:10
thanks for your time

ghaskins
2016-09-21 13:10
yw

tom.appleyard
2016-09-24 14:01
If I want to use `stub.GetCallerMetadata()` In my chaincode do I have to enable anything first? - Currently if I use this in my code it comes up with `Error:Failed to launch chaincode spec(Could not get deployment transaction for 68cacdba2816e8857c42f995d7f618c76aafbe3781bbf47a61c08d4e077dd2f0 - LedgerError - ResourceNotFound: ledger: resource not found)"`

cbf
2016-09-24 15:08
what moe are you running? -peer-chaincodedev?

arner
2016-09-26 09:20
has joined #chaincode

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 09:25
regular mode - just peer node start

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 09:29
Another quick question - can anyone explain to me what the purpose of tables are? As in why would I use CreateTable() and put data into it instead of just making a struct and using GetState()

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 09:40
Another question on top of this - why do we bother writing a `type SimpleChaincode struct {}` and then attaching all the functions in our chaincode file to this? - what purpose does it serve?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:07
@tom.appleyard tables give you query flexibility (though to be honest, the interface could be improved)

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:08
@ghaskins how do you mean 'query flexibility'?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:08
i mean, if you break up your “struct” into rows, you can query rows individually

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:09
if you glom in into one struct, you have no choice but to return the entire object

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:09
for small objects, who cares

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:09
but if, for instance, you have 100k rows….

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:09
ah right, so it's basically a way of returning bits of large objects as opposed to the entire thing?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:10
correct

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:10
(well, also for updates

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:10
its a finer granularity of your data, thats all

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:10
you can read/write smaller portions of it

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:10
which will matter (or not) depending on your data model

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:10
ah right, I see - thanks! :slightly_smiling_face:

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:11
Incidentally, I have another quick question

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:11
for fabric v0.6 how would I go about finding the name of the user whose made a chaincode invocation? (v0.5 had the common name it in the transaction certs but that's since been replaced with the string "Transaciton Certificate")

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:12
First let me answer your second question

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:12
the SimpleChaincode struct is because you need to implement the interface that supports the Init/Invoke/Query calls

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:13
you also have the opportunity to attach data, technically in a pure go sense, though this is highly discouraged for chaincode

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:13
but having the one instance gives a convenient registration point

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:13
I see, ok fair enough

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:14
third question, i havent been following the nuanced development of the tcert/ecert stuff, but I know from a high level the idea is that a TCert is intended to be an obfuscation mechanism in front of the ecert...

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:15
so whether you can decode tcert -> ecert is going to be a function of your privilege level and the configuration of the system

ghaskins
2016-09-26 13:16
if you are properly authorized, you should be able to correlate back to an underlying ecert identity…as for how to do this, I dont know the specifics

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 13:17

vzhou
2016-09-26 14:01
has joined #chaincode

vzhou
2016-09-26 14:04
Hi; if we want to store a global variable with no access restrictions, should we use the shim to add a state to the ledger, or should we use a global variable? What's the difference between the two?I'm guessing that putting the variable on the ledger makes it more secure.

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:07
I think state can be read by the chaincode (from any node) but global variable is local for the node, hmm?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:08
do not use a global variable period. It would result in a source of non determinism

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:09
all persistent state must be maintained in the ledger

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:09
do we mean a golang global variable by global variable?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:09
yes

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:09
well, really any “global variable” in chaincode, whatever platform you happen to be on

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:10
I guess that it is a good or at least 'normal' practice to have a global var with a singleton in go

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:10
no, this is not a good idea for a chaincode app

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:10
oops sorry I forgot that it is only a private one, module variable or what is the real name

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:11
I did not say that it is good for a chaincode app :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:11
heh, ok

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:11
just to be clear

vzhou
2016-09-26 14:11
Ok, that's what I kind of figured. Looks like I got some rewriting to do :slightly_smiling_face:

vzhou
2016-09-26 14:11
Thanks for the help

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:11
yes, probably standard practice in pure golang app…for chaincode, it would be a problem

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:11
right

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:12
any mutation is simply a proposed mutation until the consensus protocol runs

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:12
the network may decide to drop your mutation on the floor…and there is no communication to the chaincode app regarding the state rollback

hgabor
2016-09-26 14:13
is there anyone who knows how exactly cert attributes work? which is the right channel for this? who is the expert?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 14:14
try #membership-services

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:00
@tom.appleyard I'm also looking at that example - may be I can help

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:06
@mart0nix So in the md description of what is happening it says this a few times: "Charlie obtains, via an out-of-band channel, a TCert of Dave, let us call this certificate DaveCert;" https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/master/examples/chaincode/go/asset_management How exactly would this work?

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:07
In the sense of if I wanted to write a demo that featured that happening, how would I implement it?

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:07
Or even if I just wanted to manually step through the process

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:09
may be 'out-of-band channel' here is ambiguous

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:10
as for implementing a demo of it: just follow the example provided: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/examples/chaincode/go/asset_management/app/app.go

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:10
charlie crypto.Client charlieCert crypto.CertificateHandler

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:12
you define your 'demo' clients and you can get Tcerts for them via the intefaces (Client, Transaction Handler, Certificate Handler) as described here: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/tech/application-ACL.md

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:13
ah right

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:13
the interfaces

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:13
are they all `crypto.*`

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:16
well according to the documentation the Client interface offers a mean to get instances of Transaction Handler and Certificate Handler

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:20
ok cool, I meant that more in the sense of lines 43 and 44 have `crypto.CertificateHandler` and `crypto.Client`

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:21
if I want to use a TransactionHandler do I declare one with `crypto.TransactionHandler`?

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:21
(also could you link me where the docs mention this?) - thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:22
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/tech/application-ACL.md

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:22
charlieCert, err = charlie.GetTCertificateHandlerNext()

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:23
you define charlieCert as type crypto.CertificateHandler

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:23
but you use charlie.GetTCertificateHandlerNext() to set the variable

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:23
ah right ok

tom.appleyard
2016-09-26 15:24
cool - thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

mart0nix
2016-09-26 15:25
@tom.appleyard np

cbf
2016-09-26 16:13
@tom.appleyard you might try the #membership-services channel for tcert questions

ccooper21
2016-09-26 21:09
ok, adding a local "latest" tag to the `hyperledger/fabric-baseimage` fixed the problem. Does anyone have insight into how to fix this permanently so others don't have to muddle through such configuration details? Does a tag just need to be created in Docker Hub, or does something need to be changed in the Fabric code base to remove the dependency on this tag?

ccooper21
2016-09-26 21:13
For chain code development, I would think the Docker baseimage should be pinned to be in-sync with the Fabric code.

cbf
2016-09-26 21:25
@ccooper21 @ghaskins there is supposed to be one

ghaskins
2016-09-26 21:33
The short answer is the only mode that is truly supported right now is building from source

ghaskins
2016-09-26 21:33
If you do this, the baseimage is synthesized for you

ghaskins
2016-09-26 21:34
We are working on fixing this so you can just pull from dockerhub

ghaskins
2016-09-26 21:36
But the baseimage:latest tag is not and (Imo) will never be on docker hub

ghaskins
2016-09-26 21:36
What's happening is we are removing baseimage from runtime references

ccooper21
2016-09-26 21:39
@ghaskins I built my environment from source but it still has a dependency on the Docker Hub repository. It sounds like you are saying that is unexpected?

ghaskins
2016-09-26 22:03
Can you describe your environment (branch, vagrant devenv or custom, steps performed, etc

ccooper21
2016-09-26 22:12
I am running Fabric at AWS in an EC2 VM. I wrote a wrapper script to invoke the steps that the Packer build process uses to create the base Vagrant VM, and the same for the Vagrant `vagrant up` provisioning process.

muralisr
2016-09-26 22:12
@sstone1 there is a problem with GetRows in general where the implementation’s go routine can outlive the transaction that kicked it off and can cause errors … (will step out of the way @ghaskins @ccooper21 )

ccooper21
2016-09-26 22:12
My work is documented here https://gist.github.com/ccooper21/fb9ee6dca018885a1ced87cd5c60a935

ccooper21
2016-09-26 22:12
@ccooper21 shared a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ccooper21/F2BD9GRDK/setup-aws_sh.sh

ccooper21
2016-09-26 22:13
(If you go to the Gist page it shows documentation along with the script)

ccooper21
2016-09-26 22:15
In other words, my environment should be equivalent to the Vagrant devenv

@ccooper21: which branch of fabric?

plucena
2016-09-27 18:04
Am I missing something ?

ccooper21
2016-09-27 18:11
@plucena are you running Fabric in development or production mode?

ccooper21
2016-09-27 18:12
of I see, it looks like dev mode

ccooper21
2016-09-27 18:12
unlike with BlueMix, you need to run the chaincode locally so that it can listen and receive requests. something like this:

ccooper21
2016-09-27 18:13
``` CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.1:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=sample ./finished ```

ccooper21
2016-09-27 18:14
the difference being that BlueMix downloads your chaincode source, builds it, and hosts it in a Docker container as far as I know (i.e. it is in production mode). In development mode, which is much simpler, you must start your chaincode on your own and let it run so it can receive requests from the peer

bartman250
2016-09-27 18:28
@plucena I have put instructions here on how to run example02 locally in the simplest way on your local machine: https://github.com/Bartman250/hyperledgergetgoing

walternate
2016-09-28 12:37
I am trying here to deploy several chaincodes on Fabric... With one go file copied in the global path I can launch my application but if I put several go files in the path then the whole thing crashes. How are different contracts generally deployed by Hyperledger?

cbf
2016-09-28 12:46
@walternate all of the go chaincode needs to be reachable from $GOPATH

cbf
2016-09-28 12:47
I would place each in its own package, eg $GOPATH/src/chaincode1 $GOPATH/src/chaincode2 etc

cbf
2016-09-28 12:48
you could also take a look at fabric-chaintool as that does a lot of the packaging for you and has an opinionated structure

adc
2016-09-28 12:50
@mart0nix, I have acutally created them long time ago.

adc
2016-09-28 12:50
but many things have changed since then

adc
2016-09-28 12:51
let me try to see if I can restore its functionality

2016-09-28 12:51

2016-09-28 12:59

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:00
if you manage to run successfully the tests please write a short README so we know how to run the app and the tests : ))

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:01

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:02

walternate
2016-09-28 13:06
@cbf , so if get it well I need to package the different chaincodes in a .car file to deploy them ?

adc
2016-09-28 13:14
@mart0nix I have just checked and the tests there do not work anymore. At this point is better to remove it.

adc
2016-09-28 13:14
What you can do then is the following

adc
2016-09-28 13:14
you can setup a vp in dev mode

adc
2016-09-28 13:14
and then run the chaincode in a another shell

adc
2016-09-28 13:15
then

adc
2016-09-28 13:15
you can use the node-sdk to drive the chaincode

adc
2016-09-28 13:15
actually, under the folder sdk/node/test/unit

adc
2016-09-28 13:15
there is the file asset-mgmt-with-roles.js

adc
2016-09-28 13:15
that is what you are looking for

adc
2016-09-28 13:16
in order to successfully run it, don't forget to activate the attributes in the membership configuration file

adc
2016-09-28 13:16
aca: # Enabling/disabling Attribute Certificate Authority, if ACA is enabled attributes will be added into the TCert. enabled: true

adc
2016-09-28 13:17
you can also configure a fabric in network mode, asset-mgmt-with-roles.js deploys the chaincode

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:33
yeah I was looking at that example

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:37
so @adc - I can run three docker images (peer, membersrv and node-sdk)

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:37
execute the chaincode in the node-sdk container and then run the JS file via node.js ?

adc
2016-09-28 13:38
this is the idea :slightly_smiling_face:

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:50
@adc can you explain the following snippet in the JS test file you mentioned

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:51
``` if (devMode) { req.chaincodeName = chaincodeName; } else { req.chaincodePath = "http://github.com/asset_management_with_roles/"; }```

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:53
in devMode it's assume that the chaincode was already deployed so you just specify the chaincode ID

mart0nix
2016-09-28 13:53
while in production the JS file needs the path to deploy the chaincode ?

muralisr
2016-09-28 14:00
@mart0nix right, that is consistent with CLI, REST etc usage

cbf
2016-09-28 14:29
@walternate each would be in its own .car

cbf
2016-09-28 14:29
you can only deploy one at a time

arconederveen
2016-09-28 15:25
Hello, a question I am using the dev environment with the prefab docker containers. When I am restarting the docker containers I have to use different credentials as it seems the registered users are stored between invocations restarts. Is this assumption correct? And how can I reset them?

adc
2016-09-28 15:26
@mart0nix you are right

adc
2016-09-28 15:26
in dev mode the chaicode is assumed to be already running somewhere and connected to a validator

adc
2016-09-28 15:26
in network mode, the client-sdk deploys the chaincode

adc
2016-09-28 15:27
meaning that the peer creates a container and runs the chaincode there

cbf
2016-09-28 16:10
@arconederveen you can just remove the container and that will reset when you start again. Restarting will leave the credentials in place.

2016-09-30 12:45

muralisr
2016-09-30 13:01
@thomas.marckx there’s no restrictions on number of files that can be in a chaincode package. If golang likes it (as in `go build`), it should be fine

muralisr
2016-09-30 13:02
if you do go lang build, you should remove the generated exe before running in `net` mode

muralisr
2016-09-30 13:02
to avoid getting it included in the deployed package

thomas.marckx
2016-09-30 13:03
Perhaps this helps for everybody… You can’t extend existing types - in the case of chaincode *SimpleChaincode - in another package. This throws `cannot define new methods on non-local type global.SimpleChaincode` (I defined the struct in another package global)

thomas.marckx
2016-09-30 13:04
Thanks @muralisr … I was structuring it for readability in different files and tried to put them in different packages as well …. but apparently there are some limits :slightly_smiling_face:

fredericdgrv
2016-09-30 13:50
has joined #chaincode

manish-sethi
2016-10-03 08:17
@muralisr, @gengjh - yes `db_test_exports.go` is meant to expose the functions for tests only. @gengjh - I am not sure if I understand when you say - “I think the test code depends on another one is not a good idea”… in the setup, you have to remove folders, startDB etc.. So, dependency is natural. One way is to exposed a common function at one place and other is off course, perform this on your own. However, IMO, doing custom steps to set up is more implicit dependency e.g., if something changes in db package, the custom stuff would have more chance to break.

ranjan008

vzhou
2016-10-05 20:08
Hi, is there a way to get all of the rows in a table? It doesn't look like the shim interface directly supports this

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:09
@vzhou I'm looking for *any* examples of using the shim table

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:09
there are very few examples that I can find

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:09
it looks like it supports keys

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:09
similar to SQL

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:10
have you found any good resources so far ?

vzhou
2016-10-05 20:13
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/ceefb12425b7ccb09fc0f88dc78d395a459dca55/examples/chaincode/go/asset_management02/depository_handler.go

vzhou
2016-10-05 20:13
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/ceefb12425b7ccb09fc0f88dc78d395a459dca55/bddtests/chaincode/go/table/table.go

vzhou
2016-10-05 20:13
those are two examples

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:15
thanks

mart0nix
2016-10-05 20:15
@vzhou is this table functionality based on RocksDB or it's rather something completely new

vzhou
2016-10-05 20:15
I would think RocksDB, but I have no idea

ccooper21
2016-10-06 04:24
@mart0nix I had the same question so spent a little time looking at the shim code to answer it. The table functionality provided by the shim has nothing to do with RocksDB or the underlying data store. Rather it is just an an abstraction on top of the Fabric's blockchain key-value store. i.e. when you store a row in the table it just generates a compound key based on the table "fields" that you indicate are part of the key, and then associates the value with that compound key in the key-value store.

mart0nix
2016-10-06 06:33
@ccooper21 got it.

mart0nix
2016-10-06 06:34
I assume at one point you can do SQL-lie queries since it supports index keys

ccooper21
2016-10-06 07:07
@mart0nix kind of. lets say you have keys labeled A, B, C, and D. when I looked the API would let you search for "rows" with values for keys from left to right. i.e. you can query for A + B + C + D, A + B + C, A + B, or just A

ccooper21
2016-10-06 07:08
internally though there is no indexing or anything provided by the shim. I don't know how the blockchain is stored in RocksDB, so maybe there is some help at that underlying level. In any case, this mostly seems like a toy for building demos to me.

ccooper21
2016-10-06 07:09
the other take away that I have is that if you were to build a real application, you probably would want to use the blockchain in conjunction with a real database. e.g. the blockchain would be used to secure the data in the real database

ccooper21
2016-10-06 07:10
in my mind, there are many unresolved questions regarding how to build real applications with blockchains

mart0nix
2016-10-06 07:13
@ccooper21 if there's the KEY field type, I'd assume there's some kind of indexing

mart0nix
2016-10-06 07:14
also it looks like one can do a pseudo JOIN in code by quering two tables with these "key" fields

stevenroose
2016-10-06 07:27
has joined #chaincode

ccooper21
2016-10-06 07:55
I don't see any provided code to do a join in the shim. But, of course you could query for two data sets and do an in-memory join on your own

ccooper21
2016-10-06 07:55
if you want to take a look, the shim code is here `fabric\core\chaincode\shim\chaincode.go`

mart0nix
2016-10-06 09:30
@ccooper21 well if the KEY type is not really indexed I might as well just use regular GO structs instead of tables

vigneswaran.r

has joined #chaincode

rakoch

rakoch
2016-10-07 13:22
How to debug a chaincode ?

arner
2016-10-07 13:27
Apparently it's possible to attach a debugger like delve to the go process, but I don't know personally how to do that. It's also useful to write a lot of logging with the shim.logger. If you look at the logs of the chaincode container you can read them.

arner
2016-10-07 13:28
Did anyone succeed in using a debugger? Would be interested to learn

muralisr
2016-10-07 13:47
@arner @rakoch I have not attached a debugger myself but have heard others have with varying degrees of success. @ghaskins might know more

ghaskins
2016-10-07 13:54
yes, i use delve all the time

ghaskins
2016-10-07 13:55
all you need to do is a) install delve, b) follow the “devmode” guides, except c) prepend “dlv exec” in front of the chaincode deployment

ghaskins
2016-10-07 13:55
then you can set breakpoints, step, etc

rakoch
2016-10-07 13:59
to debug a GO it needs to be compiled with debug hooks... which added for compiler instructions. How to do that ?

ghaskins
2016-10-07 18:08
No that isn't true to my knowledge

tkuhrt
2016-10-08 00:25
has joined #chaincode

mart0nix
2016-10-08 08:39
guys how would I go about passing a JSON or XML document to the chaincode invoke method ?

mart0nix
2016-10-08 08:43
or I should include the document in the transaction payload field ?

garisingh
2016-10-08 09:32
@mart0nix - you would need to treat it as if it were any other argument to the function you are trying to invoke. For example, for JSON, if you are using NodeJS to submit - you could pass `new Buffer(JSON.stringify(myJSON))` as one of the arg

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:32
@garisingh got it

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:32
and the transaction payload field ?

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:32
What is that generally used for ?

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:33
why would you prefer the payload over a function argument

garisingh
2016-10-08 09:33
assume you are looking directly at the proto files?

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:34
well I've seen code examples where certs will be sent via the payload field

garisingh
2016-10-08 09:38
maybe that was the payload field of the ChaincodeSecurityContext message?

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:51
hmm

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:51
may be I'm confusing the metadata field with the payload

mart0nix
2016-10-08 09:52
``` // Construct the deploy request var deployRequest = { // Function to trigger fcn: "init", // Arguments to the initializing function args: [], // Mark chaincode as confidential confidential: true, // Assign Alice's cert metadata: alicesCert.encode() }; ```

matanyahu
2016-10-08 14:33
Is hyperledger fabric platform capable of running turing-complete code or are there natively embedded limitations in it?

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:32
why would you ask that? There are limitations like you're not supposed to use "global variables" and to flip coins (or do non-deterministic stuff)

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:33
I am asking in order to determine the attack surface Fabric-based network is potentially facing (and to determine if issues recently experienced by Ethereum network would also be applicable to Fabric, toutes proportions gardees, of course)

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:34
IIUC that wasn't a bug in etherium but a bug in the user code

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:35
I am talking about recent 3 weeks and not the DAO hack

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:35
oh

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:35
i.e. executing smart contracts that perform a buffer overflow on geth and parity clients

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:35
i'm uninformed then

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:36
basically, if the code is turing-complete, then it is possible to imagine all sorts of malicious intents being injected into the network through the smart contracts

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:36
with regards to Fabric the situation is even worse because the smart contract attack surface would not be mitigated by the notion of cost (i.e. gas spent to execute the contract)

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:36
what do you mean injected into the network?

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:37
you're activating a function

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:37
I mean deployed

yacovm
2016-10-08 16:37
if you have a bug in the function....

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:38
I was just curious if someone is analyzing weaknesses Ethereum network is currently going through in order to avoid similar mishaps or mitigate them within the Fabric code

ccooper21
2016-10-08 16:39
I think there is a big difference with respect to Fabric in that it is intended for private blockchains.

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:40
in what way is this difference articulated?

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:41
from a perspective of chaincode?

muralisr
2016-10-08 16:42
@ccooper21 I’d say applies to permissive, permissioned too (not strictly “private”)

ccooper21
2016-10-08 16:44
fair enough. the point being is that I wouldn't expect Fabric to be running on the public Internet where just anyone can shovel garbage calls at it. if a set of businesses are running Fabric on an internal network, and anyone attempts a DOS attack against the nodes, it should be easy enough to identify the source and shut it down

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:48
In case of the Fabric, I would implicitly put an intermediary (gateway, DMZ) before a call from the outside would reach the API. I would never let an external application to even reach nodes or query the network through the chaincode directly. However, one must assume that a Turing-complete chaincode opens a new attack surface regardless of the number of boundaries set between it and the outside world. In consortium-like environment it would be hard to enforce the same standard for security among all business participants so as an IT Architect I would not avoid asking such questions or at least documenting it as a risk

matanyahu
2016-10-08 16:49
so, coming back to my initial question: is chaincode turing-complete to the same extent as solidity-based contracts written for Ethereum network?

vu3mmg
2016-10-09 05:52
has joined #chaincode

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-10 04:05
@matanyahu As far as I understand, yes. Since Fabric supports writing chaincode in GO lang, Java which are turing complete languages. (However, I don't know about Ethereum's smart contract; so can't compare).

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-10 04:06
I think, you can create some possible attack scenarios so that fabric experts can see how those can be mitigated.

arner
2016-10-10 11:43
I think at the moment you can deploy a contract with, for instance, an endless loop an high resource usage. This could easily be mitigated by enforcing a review process for chaincode. In the current version, probably do it offline and give deploy rights to only trusted entities. In the next version, just make sure multiple (maybe even all) approving signatures are required to deploy.

zemtsov
2016-10-10 14:50
has joined #chaincode

zemtsov

Any idea?

ratnakar
2016-10-13 13:12
@pushpalatha you must have a vendor folder inside your chaincode ... If you are testing on Fabric0.5 you can refer https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo , if it is for Fabric0.6 you can download vendor.zip from the events sample https://github.com/ratnakar-asara/NodeSdkSample/tree/master/events/src/eventsender

ratnakar
2016-10-13 13:28
Otherwise you have to create a folder `vendor/github.com/hyperledger/` inside your folder where your chaincode is present and can do a `git clone https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric.git`

zemtsov
2016-10-13 13:47
Hello. I’m trying to start asset-management-with-roles example (from `hfc` package) and get this error when deploying code: ``` {"error":{"code":2,"metadata":{"_internal_repr":{}}},"msg":"Error: sql: no rows in result set"}```

zemtsov
2016-10-13 13:48
What can be wrong in my environment?

garisingh
2016-10-13 14:40
usually happens when when your peer(s) and membership services are out of sync

zemtsov
2016-10-13 14:41
is it enough just to restart them?

garisingh
2016-10-13 14:41
are you using Docker images?

zemtsov
2016-10-13 14:42
I built membersrvc and peer from hyperledger/fabric under Vagrant

garisingh
2016-10-13 14:42
and you are running hfc in Vagrant as well?

zemtsov
2016-10-13 14:42
No

zemtsov
2016-10-13 14:42
from the Host

garisingh
2016-10-13 14:43
on the host, you might want to delete `/tmp/keyValueStore`

garisingh
2016-10-13 14:44
if that fails, then delete `/tmp/keyValueStore` on the host, stop peer and CA process, do `rm -Rf /var/hyperledger` in Vagrant and then restart peer and CA processes

zemtsov
2016-10-13 14:44
Thanks, let me try

zemtsov
2016-10-13 14:51
that step passed. Thank you @garisingh

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 04:24
@warm3snow Wild guess.. By any chance you have enabled confidentiality and printing the encrypted query result as it is. If that is the case, you have to decrypt the query result.

warm3snow
2016-10-14 05:37

2016-10-14 05:44

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:08
@warm3snow In addition to enabling security and privacy, we can specify whether a chaincode is confidential or not, as used in asset_management demo. How you are doing the deployment? Using CLI method or REST APIs or client SDK?

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:21
I used CLI method. Below is my shell script ``` #!/bin/bash user="diego" passwd="DRJ23pEQl16a" login(){ echo "-----------LoginState----------------------------------------------------" GET 172.17.0.4:7050/registrar/$user sleep 1 } deploy(){ echo "------------Init--------------------------------------------------------" CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.4:7051 peer chaincode deploy \ -u $user \ -p http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/authorizable_counter \ -c '{"Function":"init", "Args":[]}' \ > chaincodeID echo `cat chaincodeID` sleep 3 } query(){ echo "------------Query------------------------------------------------------" CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.4:7051 peer chaincode query \ -u $user \ -n $ccID \ -c '{"Function":"read", "Args":[]}' sleep 1 } invoke(){ echo "------------Invoke-----------------------------------------------------" CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.4:7051 peer chaincode invoke \ -u $user \ -n $ccID \ -c '{"Function":"increment", "Args":[]}' sleep 1 } ccID=`cat chaincodeID` ccID="${ccID#*:}" case $1 in 0 ) login;; 1 ) deploy;; 2 ) invoke;; 3 ) query;; * ) echo "Error, args must be [1|2|3]";; esac ``` Is there something wrong about it?

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:21
@vigneswaran.r

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:24
And the CORE_SECURITY_PRIVACY and CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED is set in my environment variables.

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:31
@warm3snow I couldn't see anything wrong in your client application. Those security, and privacy related variables also are not a problem. Can you copy paste the chaincode query function also (it may have some changes between different versions)? Let us see if anyone gets any clue.

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:39
The deploy, query and invoke all are in the script file above. Query code is between the deploy and invoke code. ``` ./x.sh 0 --> loginState ./x.sh 1 --> deploy ./x.sh 2 -->invoke ./x.sh 3 --> query ```

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:40
@vigneswaran.r

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:40
@warm3snow No.. I asked to copy paste the chaincode example which is part of the hyperledger code.

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:41
I may have a different version of the chaincode example. That's why asking you to copy paste the query function which you have.

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:42
Only query function is sufficient..

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:44
ok, got it~~

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:49
According to this, you should pass the counter name as argument, right?

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:50
In the later versions, the query function looks like the following..

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:50
// Query callback representing the query of a chaincode func (t *AuthorizableCounterChaincode) Query(stub *shim.ChaincodeStub, function string, args []string) ([]byte, error) { if function != "read" { return nil, errors.New("Invalid query function name. Expecting \"read\"") } var err error // Get the state from the ledger Avalbytes, err := stub.GetState("counter") if err != nil { jsonResp := "{\"Error\":\"Failed to get state for counter\"}" return nil, errors.New(jsonResp) } if Avalbytes == nil { jsonResp := "{\"Error\":\"Nil amount for counter\"}" return nil, errors.New(jsonResp) } jsonResp := "{\"Name\":\"counter\",\"Amount\":\"" + string(Avalbytes) + "\"}" fmt.Printf("Query Response:%s\n", jsonResp) return Avalbytes, nil }

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:50
Very sorry, I upload the wrong pic

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:51
ok

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:51
Is your query function look like the above?

warm3snow
2016-10-14 06:52
Yes, it is

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:54
Then I have no clue what's going wrong. In order to debug, you can run the peer in development mode (--peer-chaincodedev), and run the chaincode in another terminal. Then you can see the chaincode output directly on the terminal where your chaincode is running.

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 06:56
So, you should be able to see the output of fmt.Printf("Query Response:%s\n", jsonResp), from the chaincode.

warm3snow
2016-10-14 07:00
@vigneswaran.r Thank you very very much, actually you help me a lot~~. I try it later. Thx again :slightly_smiling_face:

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-14 07:01
No problem :slightly_smiling_face:

muralisr
2016-10-16 15:50

muralisr
2016-10-16 15:52
@arvin there is a notion of chaincode-calling-chaincode (see chaincode_example05 and its use in chaincode/exectransaction_test.go for example)

arvin
2016-10-16 15:52
has joined #chaincode

muralisr
2016-10-16 15:53
its not “sending transactions” but more closer to a call under one transaction

arvin
2016-10-16 15:59
got it,there must be defined tns rules at first

muralisr
2016-10-16 16:02
if you mean some application level design/rules for chaincode-chaincode interactions , yes, that is correct

arvin
2016-10-16 16:07
is there any why i can upgrade chaincode ?

arvin
2016-10-16 16:09
for example in production environment

muralisr
2016-10-16 16:17
not in current release but definitely in 1.0 - https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-183

arvin
2016-10-16 16:21
got it , thank you very much!

muralisr
2016-10-16 16:22
anytime!

donovanhide
2016-10-16 16:22
has joined #chaincode

jov
2016-10-16 18:14
has joined #chaincode

jov
2016-10-16 18:18
Hi are there any guidlines about designing the chaincode. Like splitting up the application over different chaincode?

muralisr
2016-10-16 18:54
@jov transactions sent two chaincodes are two different transactions. A transaction sent to a chaincode which calls another is just one transaction (although each chaincode has a different namespace). Given these two would dictate how the entire application stack (and chaincode along with it) should be organized for the chain under consideration.

conghonglei
2016-10-17 01:16
has joined #chaincode

swood
2016-10-17 04:26

vigneswaran.r
2016-10-19 09:16
@teddy I think, you can return ([]byte(keys), nil) from createAccount. I am assuming that the variable "keys" has private & public key separated by some delimiter such as "\n". However, it would be better to create the keys from the client side and only send the public key to the createAccount() function as a parameter (instead of generating keys from within createAccount).

2016-10-19 10:05

ranjan008
2016-10-19 10:07
can anyone specify what for event is used in chaincode???

miro
2016-10-19 10:16
has joined #chaincode

grapebaba
2016-10-19 13:43
@muralisr: someone has question about how to deal with time in chaincode, use time.Now() seems multiple peer inconsistent

muralisr
2016-10-19 13:48
@grapebaba thanks. you are right. using time functions for computations would make it non-deterministic and lead to divergence

muralisr
2016-10-19 13:51
@ranjan008 events from chaincode (also called “custom events”) adds support for notification. Benefits are minimize polling from application, notification specific to chaincode for a transaction etc. Note that the event is sent on successful commit and not on execution.

grapebaba
2016-10-19 13:52
have any method to replace time usage?

hgabor
2016-10-19 13:53

tom.appleyard
2016-10-20 09:26
Hey All, would someone be able to explain using tables to me? Specifically - when you make a table I get the idea that you specify the columns and what each column is called and contains but what does the 'key' field mean? Likewise, when you do a search for a row in a table you do so by something like this: ```var columns []shim.Column col1 := shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_String_{String_: args[0]}} columns = append(columns, col1) col2 := shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_String_{String_: args[1]}} columns = append(columns, col2) col3 := shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_String_{String_: args[2]}} columns = append(columns, col3) row, err := stub.GetRow("RequestTable", columns) ``` The table the above searches contains 7 columns yet in this only 3 are specified - what is happening here? - So far as I can see what is happening is that 3 column objects are being made containing the arguments put in (I assume these arguments are values to be searched for?). However the column objects in the array don't seem to be given any kind of identifier that might link them to the columns in the table (apart from the type) as such how does the table know which column in the table to compare them to?

ranjan008
2016-10-20 12:51
@garisingh is it possible to write self executing methods after certain intervals

garisingh
2016-10-20 12:55
no - you should not develop chaincode which attempts to use timers to trigger functions. You would need to build the timer which injects transactions outside of the fabric as a client

msoumeit
2016-10-20 15:18
has joined #chaincode

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 16:25
@tom.appleyard When I used tables, usually you query the table based on the key. So in your example, I would guess that col1, col2, and col3 are marked as keys that you are querying on.

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 16:25
And the matching would be based on the ordering of the keys defined in the table.

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 16:26
@ranjan008 : events are asynchronous. You can put any value in the event, but it is not something that the client that called invoke will get as a response to the invoke. You need a separate event listener to listen for and handle the event when the transaction is added to a block.

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 16:28
@arvin : not sure if I understand your question about getting transactions clear text, but the payload in the transaction is base64 encoded.

dvitas
2016-10-20 16:53
has joined #chaincode

2016-10-20 16:53
