2016-10-20 16:56
Is there a way to get the affiliation of a user in Golang chaincode?

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 16:57
It seems that the attributes do not currently work in the latest code, and I am looking to add some authorization checks to my chaincode.

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 16:58
So I thought if I could get my hands on the affiliation of a user, then I could just check the affiliation.

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-20 20:55
How do I deploy compiled chaincode to a remote peer in production setting?

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-20 20:57
In dev mode I can do the following:

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-20 20:57
{ "jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "deploy", "params": { "type": 1, "chaincodeID":{ "name":"mycc" }, "ctorMsg": { "function":"init", "args":["a", "values"] } }, "id": 3 }

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-20 20:57
But, I need to give ChaincodeID path in production mode. How do I do that?

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-20 20:58
when I deployed the CC like:

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-20 20:58
CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=http://my-root-peer.net:7051 ./mycc

tkuhrt
2016-10-20 21:59
@sandeep.kanaparthi in addition to utilizing name, you must specify the http://github.com path of the repo containing the chaincode.

muralisr
2016-10-20 22:51
@sandeep.kanaparthi you’d specify “name” for deploying a chaincode only in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode… when not using dev mode, you’d need a path (as @tkuhrt points out above). There was a discussion around this in `fabric` channel on Oct. 16

t-watana
2016-10-21 00:21
has joined #chaincode

sandeep.kanaparthi
2016-10-21 01:26
Thank you @muralisr for pointing me to the discussion on 10/16 on #fabric on this topic. That discussion clears some of my questions. But, I am little surprised that the only way to deploy the code to production mode fabric network is through public repo. Hope things will change by 1.0 release.

2016-10-21 02:05

2016-10-24 12:15

My env variables are: ``` CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG CORE_LOGGING_CHAINCODE=DEBUG ``` My main function does this: ```golang var logger = shim.NewLogger("mycc") func main() { shim.SetLoggingLevel(shim.LogDebug) shim.SetChaincodeLoggingLevel() err := shim.Start(new(MyChaincode)) if err != nil { logger.Errorf("Error starting Simple chaincode: %s", err) } } ``` And the Init function fails without logging anything, not the error, nor the message I tell it to print: ```golang func (t *MyChaincode) Init(stub shim.ChaincodeStubInterface) ([]byte, error) { logger.Debug("Initializing...") [...] ```

umasuthan
2016-10-25 10:27
Are there any restrictions on invoking REST APIs from Chaincode? Or is it a bad practice to invoke external methods from chain code?

muralisr
2016-10-25 10:40
@umasuthan the later … it could lead to nondeterministic behavior (what if the called failed on one of the peers)

umasuthan
2016-10-25 10:42
@muralisr, In that case we can fail the transaction, right? I mean the status of ledger is unchanged

muralisr
2016-10-25 10:43
it is post consensus. … it will fail on one peer and not on others and will cause ledger divergence

zemtsov
2016-10-25 10:44
@umasuthan there is a proper way to call one chaincode from another, if this is what you want

umasuthan
2016-10-25 10:45
Not exactly, My thoughts are like this. Peer1 invoke a transaction on the chain code. That method implementation in turn invokes a REST service and it fails. Now, can’t I fail the transaction altogether and return an error to Peer1?

umasuthan
2016-10-25 10:46
@zemtsov, I am thing of a usecase where I will let the chaincode do some rule executions, which are exposed as services

tkuhrt
2016-10-26 16:31
@warm3snow: I believe it is because attributes are no longer working in the latest source code. See: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/core/chaincode/shim/crypto/attr/attr_support.go#L122. It appears that attributes need to be re-designed. If anyone knows how to add authorization to chaincode, please let me know.

mike_wall
2016-10-28 14:49
I found mistake. This tutorial just outdated https://console.ng.bluemix.net/docs/services/blockchain/ibmblockchain_tutorials.html. `have Init(*shim.ChaincodeStub, string, []string) ([]byte, error) want Init(shim.ChaincodeStubInterface) ([]byte, error)`

vdods
2016-11-02 22:23
has joined #chaincode

vdods
2016-11-02 22:26
I'd like to get some clarification on how the key-columns in chaincode tables work. They're clearly used to identify rows in a given table. Can a given table have more than one key-column?

vdods
2016-11-02 22:28
The comments in core/chaincode/shim/interfaces.go:GetRows suggest there can be more than one key -- but then what does GetRow do? Does it have to have all keys specified such that the row is uniquely identified?

tkuhrt
2016-11-02 23:08
@vdods : Use CreateTable to create the table. Then you use GetRow to query for all keys in the table. GetRows allows you to query by a subset of keys.

tkuhrt
2016-11-02 23:10
So if you CreateTable and specify column A and B as keys, you can use GetRow to query for the row that matches A and B. Or you could use GetRows to return all the rows with values that match A.

vdods
2016-11-03 02:14
@tkuhrt Thanks!

sumitks
2016-11-03 05:41
has joined #chaincode

tom.appleyard
2016-11-03 06:19
Hey All, regarding how tables work in Hyperledger can anyone explain to me _why_ they are are set up like this - I mean what advantage is there to not allowing the user to specify an arbitrary key and search on it and forcing them to do `GetRows()` with a linear combination of them?

warm3snow
2016-11-03 06:41
@tom.appleyard Personally, the table interfaces are hard to use and not efficient. It's a better way directly to use the GetState() and PutState(). I think GetRows() is used for range query (just set the parameter 'key' to nil). For specifying an arbitrary key, use the GetRow(). Hope will help you.

tom.appleyard
2016-11-03 07:27
@warm3snow Sure thing - I'm more after the reasoning behind it's setup rather than advice on how to use it though, I agree it's difficult to use which makes me wonder why it was designed that way

hiepnm
2016-11-03 07:44
I used the postman to deploy 2 chaincodes (chaincode_example02 & chaincode_example01) to a blockchain network with 4 peers. And after deploying, I got more 8 containers. Why did peer do that?

hiepnm
2016-11-03 07:45
@hiepnm uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/hiepnm/F2WN3Q9DE/-.txt

sstone1
2016-11-03 08:09
@hiepnm each peer runs it's own copy of each deployed chaincode in a separate Docker container. You have 4 peers and 2 deployed chaincodes so you get 4 * 2 chaincode containers.

hiepnm
2016-11-03 08:16
@sstone1 1st chaincode I set A=100 (WorldState), 2nd chaincode I set A = 200. How many is A value I get?

hiepnm
2016-11-03 08:17
@sstone1 Thank you very much.

hiepnm
2016-11-03 08:18
I have a "4 peers" blockchain network with pbft consensus (vp0, vp1, vp2, vp3). I used postman (to generate post REST API) to deploy a chaincode (chaincode_example02, A=100, B=200) in to this network, and get more 4 containers that run my chaincode. I call Invoked transaction to vp0 to get the result like this (A-5, B+5 => A=95, B=205). Then, I requested QUERY to vp3 to get A value. I got A=95. It's OK. And then, I stop peer vp3, and restart it. After that, I call query request to vp3 to get A value. But, I got A=100 (like after chaincode deploy). Why did I get A=100 instead of 95?

sstone1
2016-11-03 08:19
World state is partitioned by chaincode ID, so the 1st and 2nd chaincodes see different 'A's

hiepnm
2016-11-03 08:20
@sstone1 thank you. I have more statement like above. Can you help me?

sstone1
2016-11-03 08:31
I don't know the answer to the vp3 restart problem I'm afraid. Put the questions in the Slack?

hiepnm
2016-11-03 08:35
@sstone1 thank you

hiepnm
2016-11-03 08:36
@warm3snow and all: I'm looking forward to see your answers.

warm3snow
2016-11-03 09:06
@hiepnm The fabric network can not support dynamic join, I vaguely remembered a developer said that before. Also, i think when you restart the vp3, maybe your specify the wrong container id.

hiepnm
2016-11-03 09:09
@warm3snow thank you. I restarted vp3, with the correct ID. When I stopped vp3 container, the chaincode container attached with vp3 also stopped.

hiepnm
2016-11-03 09:46
@sstone1 @warm3snow I have just replayed with my problem. It has returned right (A=95 on vp3). I don't know the reason. :disappointed:

hiepnm
2016-11-03 10:01
How do I get all transactions in my ledger? And I want to get information (world state,....) of a transaction in history. What can I do?

cbf
2016-11-03 13:21
@hiepnm you can query the state if you know the key… as for seeing the transactions, you can use the blockchain-explorer to visualize what is in there

cbf
2016-11-03 13:21
there is no way to retrieve the entire contents of the ledger

cypher

I need a sample chaincode from which I can build my own version. The ones I got from https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/marbles-chaincode and https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode gave build errors regarding function signatures.

garisingh
2016-11-06 11:05
@cypher - are you using the Fabric v0.6 Docker images?

cypher
2016-11-06 11:18
@garisingh I deployed the blockchain network from IBM bluemix dashboard. So not sure about the version. I found a working chaincode from the following link which I just got from the marbles' application's app.js file https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/marbles-chaincode/hyperledger/part1/ It works well when I deploy it. But when I build it locally I get the following error: .\chaincode.go:50: cannot use new(SimpleChaincode) (type *SimpleChaincode) as type shim.Chaincode in argument to shim.Start: *SimpleChaincode does not implement shim.Chaincode (wrong type for Init method) have Init(*shim.ChaincodeStub, string, []string) ([]byte, error) want Init(shim.ChaincodeStubInterface) ([]byte, error)

garisingh
2016-11-06 11:27
@cypher - is your goal to be able to run the chaincode locally against Docker images of the Fabric or are you just trying to make some changes and compile locally to ensure that it actually compiles?

cypher
2016-11-06 11:27
@garisingh Just to compile locally to make sure it works before deploying it :slightly_smiling_face:

cypher
2016-11-06 11:30
So I also cloned the fabric repository to my local machine since there are references to http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim

cypher
2016-11-06 11:30
just to avoid compilation errors

garisingh
2016-11-06 11:34
yeah - the problem is that the current version of Fabric in github is v0.6 and BMX uses v0.5 and the chaincode interfaces are different (BTW - this problem will go away with new instances of the BMX service later this week when we finally upgrade to v0.6). The easiest thing to do is to have a look at https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/cc-commercialpaper/tree/v1.0 and you can copy the `vendor` folder into the root of the marbles chaincode on your machine (and things will compile)

cypher
2016-11-06 12:01
Thank you @garisingh I'll try it :slightly_smiling_face:

khaleshah
2016-11-06 12:35
has joined #chaincode

cypher
2016-11-06 12:39
@garisingh Same error with that too. I think I have to replicate a different version of fabric repository in my local machine

cypher
2016-11-06 12:53
@garisingh The current fabric code I'm having in my local machine is replicated from https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric Can you please give me the link for a suitable version?

garisingh
2016-11-06 12:54
https://github.com/hyperledger-archives/fabric/archive/v0.5-developer-preview.zip

pd93
2016-11-07 10:21
@snehalpansare Not sure about the malformed response, but shouldn't it be "/var/run/docker.sock" not "/var/run/docker/sock"

ghaskins
2016-11-07 11:36
https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/dockerimages/p1478518175000360

ghaskins
2016-11-07 11:37
@pd93 I took that to be a typo/faulty-memory and not the literal error message

ghaskins
2016-11-07 11:38
@snehalpansare BTW, the format of the variable looks like "CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=http://172.17.0.1:2375"

ghaskins
2016-11-07 11:38
heres a working example: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/bddtests/compose-defaults.yml

snehalpansare
2016-11-07 12:00
@pd93 @ghaskins I bypassed docker.sock error , now I am getting a new error - Error building images: Tag latest not found in repository http://docker.io/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:37
@snehalpansare the short answer is: binary deployment is not yet supported (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-678)

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:37
the long answer is, you can work around it (for now) if you really want to

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:37
it will eventually be more turnkey

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:39
long story short, the only deployment model that is truly supported right now is building the fabric from source, as baseimage:latest is synthesized by the build

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:39
but if you are willing to rejigger a few things, you can get your environment aligned so it will run

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:40
i assume you are running v0.6.1-preview?

ghaskins
2016-11-07 12:41
@snehalpansare ^^^^

arulmurugan
2016-11-09 09:27
has joined #chaincode

donaldsbell
2016-11-09 14:47
has joined #chaincode

jov
2016-11-10 08:23
Hi, I have a question about querying tables. I have a table with 3 keys. Example: Surname, Name, RegistryNumber. If I perform a Lookup with all 3 keys, I'll receive one row. I perform a lookup with keys: Surname, Name, I receive 1 or more rows. But when I do a lookup by the third key only. I don't receive any information. I perform the lookup as such: nill,nill, RegistryNumber. How do I perform a lookup with only the third Key and the other blank values?

muralisr
2016-11-10 13:40
@jov the simple answer is that the table support is limited and you cannot query (nil, nil, RegistryNumber). Any keybased query ending in a key has to have all the previous keys. (@dave.enyeart to correct.)

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 13:40
has joined #chaincode

k.sung
2016-11-10 13:55
has joined #chaincode

jov
2016-11-10 14:05
@musalisr, That was my understanding as well. Thanks for the confirmation. I'll try to find another way to circumvent the issue.

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:02
@muralisr That is correct. The table API is misleading in that you can’t query arbitrary columns. For v1 we are recommending to use JSON data in chaincode rather than table API, so when using a state database that supports JSON query (such as CouchDB), any field in the chaincode variable can be queried.

garisingh
2016-11-10 16:08
@dave.enyeart - did we decide to remove the table API in v1 (and just expose the range queries) or are we leaving it in?

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:09
@garisingh is there a discussion/doc about the chaincode kv interface plans?

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:09
I know that we use the table API, and even that is fairly weak for what we would like to see

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:10
so, if its going away, id like to know what the plan is in general

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:10
e.g. I'd hate to see it get weaker by table simply going away...id rather see it grow stronger

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:12
that is the goal… to make it stronger to support query on any field. we can get there by using JSON data in chaincode and CouchDB as the state database. Whether we completely remove the fairly limited Table API is still up for debate.

sstone1
2016-11-10 16:17
@dave.enyeart has there been any thoughts on what the chaincode API (for chaincode developers) would look like when it is backed by CouchDB?

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:18
@dave.enyeart having some kind of formal query engine would be a welcome addition

cypher
2016-11-10 16:19
Is there any SDK available for crypto-currency type use case? I mean it should be readily consumable by a front-end designed to make a simple peer-to-peer crypto currency transactions.

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:19
my thought is, I would be careful about exposing any one particular engine (unless its super general, like SQL)

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:19
but even that, i dont have a strong opinion other than to say building apps on top of the v0.6 and earlier architecture is a bit weak

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:19
so, anything that improves that is welcome

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:21
for now we still use PutState() and pass the bytes. If we detect those bytes represent JSON then we store in CouchDB as JSON, otherwise store in CouchDB as binary attachment. We may make this more explicit and allow the chaincode developer to call PutStateJSON() or PutStateJSONwithBinaryAttachments().

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:23
PutStateJSONwithBinaryAttachments() would allow you to save some queryable JSON ‘header’ information to the ledger, along with binary attachments such as PDF, JPG, etc

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:25
All - what are the most typical use cases for query that we are seeing? a) query to see what is in ledger or b) query for purpose of determining which keys to update in a transaction?

jov
2016-11-10 16:39
@dave.enyeart For me, I query the most to see what's in the ledger

sstone1
2016-11-10 16:47
@dave.enyeart Same for me. One of the things I would find lacking without the table support is how to deal with collections of things - using the car lease demo as an example, I want a collection of cars - I want to get all the cars, I want to get a car by its ID, and ideally I could use a query language to get a car using expressions that can access any of the car's properties.

sstone1
2016-11-10 16:48
I don't know much about CouchDB but maybe just storing JSON representations of the cars with some kind of "class" marker would be enough to achieve that with GetState()/PutState() and I assume some kind of Query() method?

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:52
right, we could decide to write our own query language on top of key/value database. haven’t ruled that out, but for short term it is easier to use a database such as CouchDB that already has that.

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:53
right, or use one that exists

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:54
long story short: some abstraction between the chaincode's interface and the underlying ledger implementation is probably smart, but i agree for the short term its probably fine to surface something less general

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:55
out of curiosity: why couchdb? what else was looked at?

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:55
im just curious

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:55
I remember looking at couchdb years ago, but i came away relatively unimpressed

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:56
IIRC I found its MR facilities were a little too static to be what I deemed useful...i was more enthusiastic about dynamo derivatives like Riak

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:56
not saying that is appropriate here, I am just curious what the rationale was

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:56
sql based data stores were looked at, but required maintenance of schema which is awkward given our development model

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:57
what is MR?

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:57
map-reduce

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:57
may not apply here

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:57
that was what I was looking at at that time

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:57
ah, CouchDB in 2.0 has added ad hoc query that does not require map reduce

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:57
that makes it much nicer to work with… same idea as sql and mongo query, but different syntax

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:57
I seem to recall that I found couchdb a little too static because you had to bake the code in, whereas in Riak you could provide ad hoc queries

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:58
ah, gotcha

ghaskins
2016-11-10 16:58
its been a while since I looked at it, so I am sure its completely evolved at this point

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 16:59
yes, the ad hoc query makes it much nicer for our use

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 17:00
couchdb and mongodb are both good candidates, since the json document approach is similar enough to our core key/value concepts, with good ad hoc query on any fields

nikileshsa
2016-11-10 17:02
https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/chaincode/p1478797007002252 . @dave.enyeart your initial pluggable state DB presentation had DB2 also as a suggested. Will this still be tried?

nikileshsa
2016-11-10 17:05
I mean as a proof of concept..or something to show that schema management would be an issue

dave.enyeart
2016-11-10 17:08
when we mapped out all the steps it became obvious that schema management and the extra transformation layer to tables was painful. therefore the focus for v1 is on json document store and making the persistence layer pluggable, so that others could add the sql based support if needed

nikileshsa
2016-11-10 17:09
got it..

lanzen
2016-11-10 19:00
has joined #chaincode

dennism330
2016-11-11 00:42
has joined #chaincode

pushpalatha
2016-11-11 03:59
Hi All, In production mode, if i want to refer to some static file from my chain code where do i need to keep it and how to refer it?

ghaskins
2016-11-11 14:01
I had already responded to @pushpalatha in a DM, but wanted to respond again here for all to see

ghaskins
2016-11-11 14:01
the short answer is: i do not believe we can do this today, but I think its a perfectly reasonable thing to request...i think we could easily support it (particularly in CAR, but elsewhere too)

ghaskins
2016-11-11 14:02
we should have a JIRA for this feature

2016-11-13 15:42
TestMockTable to be specific

muralisr
2016-11-13 15:42
right

muralisr
2016-11-13 15:43
I would stay off GetRows on master for now. Has been fixed in 0.6 but not in master with all the changes going on ther

2016-11-13 15:43

muralisr
2016-11-13 15:43
sure

msoumeit
2016-11-14 16:47
@nikileshsa I tried following the steps to deploy chaincode ( https://lists.hyperledger.org/pipermail/hyperledger-fabric/attachments/20161022/d3860afb/attachment.obj ) Getting the following error while deploying Chaincode 02 16:31:48.717 [chaincode] Deploy -> DEBU 09e deploying chaincode CC02(networkid:dev,peerid:jdoe) 16:31:49.266 [dockercontroller] deployImage -> ERRO 09f Error building images: API error (500): {"message":"Error parsing reference: \"dev-jdoe-CC02\" is not a valid repository/tag"} Please advise. thanks

ikruiper
2016-11-14 17:15
hey @nhrishi : how does your invokeRequest payload looks like? usually you need to specify which attributes you want to present to the chaincode, as well as the cert itself...so something like this (if you want to present `attr1` and `attr2`): ``` const invokeRequest = { chaincodeID: 'myChainCodeId', fcn: 'funcName', args: args, confidential: true, attrs: ['attr1', 'attr2'], userCert: userCertObj }; const tx = user.invoke(invokeRequest); ```

ikruiper
2016-11-14 17:23
I have an issue on the return of a chainCode Invoke call (which is supposed to insert a row via the `stub.InsertRow` function...here is the problem: ```[chaincode] processStream -> ERRO 11f Got error: Error unmarshalling table: unexpected EOF``` Using hfc 0.6.5 (but also tried 0.6.2) and using the `x86_64-0.6.1-preview` docker images : if you have seen this before, I would appreciate any pointers...cheers!

kletkeman
2016-11-14 20:17
Having a bit of trouble deploying my latest iot chaincode sample ... I've split it into a tiny chaincode client and an "iot contract platform" that it imports ... the docker build for chaincode executes go install instead of go get and so does not find the package. Go get plus go install work fine, so this is a problem for me. Is the solution that I have to vendor our platform? Or is it an error that go install is used when go get would handle more cases (like ours)?

nhrishi
2016-11-15 01:39
@ikruiper: thanks! Yes I'm setting attrs. I'm not setting confidential and userCert, will it make any difference? About your error, not exactly sure what is the issue but does your columns in insertRow match table definition.

ikruiper
2016-11-15 09:28
the confidential won't make any difference here, but the userCert should (user.cert)

garisingh
2016-11-15 13:10
@kletkeman - you are going to need to vendor your "extra" package

garisingh
2016-11-15 13:11
(I'll assume you are using the SDK to deploy)

kroisin
2016-11-15 15:15
has joined #chaincode

kletkeman
2016-11-15 15:30
Thanks Gary, I figured it out yesterday with Greg's help. I debug using REST, which is by far the handiest way to do it, although if need be I can add it to our Monitoring UI. It's stuck in REST land too, though (for now.) I used govendor to vendor all dependencies and it worked great with fast build times on Bluemix.

pushpalatha
2016-11-16 12:41
Hi All, If the chain code breaks at some point, i see that the handler itself is getting de-registered. [chaincode] processStream -> ERRO cd32 Error handling chaincode support stream: stream error: code = 1 desc = "context canceled" Deregister handler: How do we actually prevent de-registering? instead i just want to throw an error and continue.. Please suggest.

yacovm
2016-11-16 12:54
what do you mean throw an error? if the process dies it dies. If you catch the error and recover, it doesn't die.

nhrishi
2016-11-16 13:46
@ikruiper How are you acquiring userCert. As I understand, HFC will get TCert while doing invoke internally, so dont need to pass cert explicitly

claudiu

claudiu
2016-11-22 14:22
Hi, I am trying to filter one a table by it's 3th column, this is my code ``` var columns []shim.Column col3 := shim.Column{Value:&shim.Column_Uint64{Uint64:authorizerID}} //authorizerID is the parameter I want to filter on rowChannel, err := stub.GetRows("RequestTable", columns) ``` My problem is now that this line of code does not filter on the 3th column, but on the first. I also have tried this: ``` col1 := shim.Column{Value:nil} col2 := shim.Column{Value:nil} col3 := shim.Column{Value:&shim.Column_Uint64{Uint64:authorizerID}} columns = append(columns, col1) columns = append(columns, col2) columns = append(columns, col3) ``` But then I got nothing back from `stub.GetRows("RequestTable", columns)` Is there a way to skip the first and the second column, and filter on the 3th?

claudiu
2016-11-22 14:26
ps I am using Fabric 0.6

warm3snow
2016-11-22 15:50
Did you set the 3th column the key field when you do createTable? The table must have a key field, If you set 3th column the key, it'll work.

warm3snow
2016-11-22 15:50
@claudiu

claudiu
2016-11-22 16:14
@warm3snow yes I have ``` &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: "RequestID", Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_UINT64, Key: true}, &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: "IssuerID", Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_UINT64, Key: true}, &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: "AuthorizerID", Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_UINT64, Key: true}, ```

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 12:22
hey all. this is probably a dumb question but could someone explain to be exactly what 'deploying' chaincode refers to? In the sense that I understand you can manually compile chaincode and then connec this to a peer or you can package it up and send it to a peer

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 12:23
if you manually compile it and connect to a peer you still have to run `peer chaincode deploy `

cbf
2016-11-23 12:59
@tom.appleyard deploying chaincode is just what it sounds like it means: basically, you push the code for a chaincode to a peer network and it is compiled and run on the peer nodes in its own docker container

cbf
2016-11-23 13:00
the mode you described is for development/test only

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 13:31
so what I described - when I run `peer chaincode deploy` what happens?

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 13:31
if it isn't deploying

vibhu
2016-11-23 13:45
has joined #chaincode

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:49
@tom.appleyard - when running in dev mode, `peer chaincode deploy` registers the chaincode with the peer

muralisr
2016-11-23 13:58
right. `deploy` can be thought of as `start + initialize`. In dev mode user has started ..deploy is used to initialize (using the “-c” param)

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 14:10
ok, can you explain the difference between `start`, `initialise` and `register`?

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 14:13
and if `deploy` is `start + initialise` where does making the chaincode into a docker image come into it?

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 16:51
different question now

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 16:51
(but thanks for the answers :slightly_smiling_face: )

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 16:51
when we have deploy transactions on teh blockchain

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 16:52
what is stored in one of them

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 16:52
I assume it's more a reference to the chaincode rather than the source itself

tom.appleyard
2016-11-23 16:52
and presumably this reference is done in such a way that a new peer is able to say "could you send me this" to the other peers

sstone1
2016-11-24 18:43

bain
2016-11-25 02:01
@sstone1 I got it. Thanks.

vigneswaran.r
2016-11-25 06:54
@claudiu If you make all the three fields in your table as key fields, then you can't filter only based on 3rd field. You can do in the following combinations only, 1. select rows based on 1st field value 2. select rows based on 1st and 2nd fields' values 3. select rows based on 1st, 2nd and 3rd fields' values If you want to select the rows based only on 3rd field, please make only 3rd row as key. (set false to others).

vigneswaran.r
2016-11-25 06:55
sorry, 3rd filed as key (not 3rd row, in my last line)..

pjhaga
2016-11-29 13:07
Hi All, I am new here, so I hope this is the right place for my question. I was wondering if someone could explain whether the getRows function works when using tables in your blockchain, and if so, could someone explain me how I can use it?

vibhu
2016-11-29 13:32
Hey Guys - trying to run the example02 chaincode. I was able to deploy with the two entities - peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Args": ["init", "vibhu","100", "rocky", "200"]}' however when I try to invoke using the cmd peer chaincode invoke -l golang -n mycc -c '{"Args": ["invoke", "vibhu", "rocky", "10"]}' i get the error Error: Error endorsing chaincode: rpc error: code = 2 desc = Error deploying chaincode: Failed to launch chaincode spec(Could not get deployment transaction from LCCC for mycc - Error deploying chaincode: Transaction or query returned with failure: transaction not found default/mycc) ..... any ideas why?

tkuhrt
2016-11-29 16:12
@pjhaga: Have you had a look at https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/core/chaincode/shim/mockstub_test.go#L75? This is the test function for getRows. It should give you some insight.

umasuthan
2016-11-30 05:12
Need help on Immutability aspect in Blockchain/Hyperledger. When we create Chaincode, we use the Shim provided capability to create tables in RocksDB. During transaction invocation on chaincode, we insert and update data in these tables. Blockchain promises immutability which means updates will not be allowed. However, we are able to update the data on RocksDB. My questions are, 1. What is the immutability that is provided by Hyperledger 2. I am able to update the records in the DB, because, those tables are created by me, what kind of data gets stored by blockchain. In other words can I avoid creating tables and still invoke transactions? If so agains what the transactions will be invoked? Do we have any samples?

xixuejia
2016-11-30 05:55
@umasuthan 1. the immutability means the blocks generated are immutable, you can't alter/delete blocks

xixuejia
2016-11-30 05:56
2. you can invoke tx w/o creating tables. just see the example02 sample

umasuthan
2016-11-30 05:57
Does the block store any data other than the hash? Also, if we have tables and create records, how do we correlate the actions on records and the blocks?

umasuthan
2016-11-30 05:58
I will check our example 2

xixuejia
2016-11-30 05:59
yes, block also stores payload, timestamp, nonhash data, etc..

xixuejia
2016-11-30 06:00
block contains your tx in payload, it's like an event, your state(data in tables) will change based on the tx data in block

xixuejia
2016-11-30 06:02
blocks are like event sourcing, you can play back your state based on the block chain

xixuejia
2016-11-30 06:04
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v0.6/protos/fabric.proto#L89

umasuthan
2016-11-30 06:38
@xixuejia , Thank you so much for pointers. I will go through and get back if I need any further help.

umasuthan
2016-11-30 06:47
The Block Message has an attribute nonHashData of type NonHashData - Data stored with the block, but not included in the blocks // hash. This allows this data to be different per peer or discarded without // impacting the blockchain.

umasuthan
2016-11-30 06:48
What exactly do we mean by "This allows this data to be different per peer or discarded without impacting the blockchain"

umasuthan
2016-11-30 06:49
I assume this is where the data gets stored. Does it get encrypted also for privacy?

xixuejia
2016-11-30 06:55
NonHashData doesn't participate hash process, it only stores local peer data and doesn't change the hash of block. Actually, Transaction is where data is stored I think. It should be encrypted if you enable privacy option

xixuejia
2016-11-30 06:57
when calculating Block hash, NonHashData is ignored

umasuthan
2016-11-30 07:02
Ok. So the payload content is participating in calculating Block hash, right? My definition of payload is that, if I am implementing an asset management solution using hyper ledger, the asset details such as its dimensions and other attributes will be the payload.

pjhaga
2016-11-30 08:17
@tkuhrt Yea I've seen a similar example like that one. And these examples work. However, this only seems to work if you specify the first key column. What I want to do is that when a table has two key columns, I want to use the getRows only specifying a value for the second key column, and this is something I can't get to work. We also looked at the code of the getRows function and checked how it worked, and we think that the function is not capable of what we want to achieve.

tom.appleyard
2016-11-30 11:07
Where would I go to find the docs for these: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/v0.6/membersrvc/ca ?

tkuhrt
2016-11-30 17:11
@pjhaga: you are correct. You can only use getRows using the keys in order. So if you have three keys (k1, k2, k3), you can query on k1 or k1,k2 or k1,k2,k3, but you cannot query on k1,k3 or k2,k3 or k2 or k3.

tkuhrt
2016-11-30 17:11
in the case of querying on k1,k2,k3 your would use getRow though.

tkuhrt
2016-11-30 17:12
I haven’t tried getRows specifying all the keys

jordan
2016-11-30 22:45
has joined #chaincode

daniellee
2016-12-01 01:38
has joined #chaincode

daniellee
2016-12-01 02:20
Quick Question: Any proper way to remove deployed chaincodes (their docker container as way). They consumed many disk space.

pjhaga
2016-12-01 08:11
@tkuhrt is it possible to leave a few keys empty. So for example if I have three keys (k1, k2, k3), can I leave k1 empty so that I so that I search with all three keys, but I don't care what is in k1?

tkuhrt
2016-12-01 16:35
I have never tried it, @pjhaga. Pretty sure I saw somewhere on this Slack that you cannot do that though.

ruslan.ardashev
2016-12-02 13:45
lol @jjmiranda . this seems like regular chaincode. I saw the term “system” chaincodes used in the v1 arch doc that sounded different from regular chaincode

garisingh
2016-12-02 14:14
development wise its the same code / interface. the difference is it needs to be registered and compiled as part of the peer executable

garisingh
2016-12-02 14:15
not sure it was ever documented outside the code you should be able to see how to do the register in the system_chaincode package

ruslan.ardashev
2016-12-02 14:22
oh ok. that makes sense. was under the impression there was some hidden, awesome functionality that I have yet to learn of: )

2016-12-02 17:50

sekharkumarroy
2016-12-05 13:28
has joined #chaincode

cbf
2016-12-05 15:06
@donjohnny there are a couple of ways you can get running with Fabric

cbf
2016-12-05 15:07
the first is to directly leverage the published Docker images with something we call the Fabric starter kit http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/starter/fabric-starter-kit/

cbf
2016-12-05 15:08
you don't need to build from source; you can just start things with Docker Compose and build off of the provided sample app

cbf
2016-12-05 15:08
this is all currently based on v0.6 images

cbf
2016-12-05 15:09
the second mode is for the more adventurous, and that would involve building from source

cbf
2016-12-05 15:09
however, there isn't much in published documentation on how to get things running

cbf
2016-12-05 15:09
this is coming soon

cbf
2016-12-05 15:10
LMK whether you want to be on the bleeding edge or if you would prefer working with a more stable version of the code

2016-12-05 21:51
has joined #chaincode

synblockchainteam
2016-12-06 15:07
has joined #chaincode

synblockchainteam
2016-12-06 15:07
Hi, Please let me know if this forum provides solutions regarding "hyperledger v0.6" related queries. Thanks.

donjohnny
2016-12-06 15:45
Hi, I have a question regarding chaincode application architecture. (just picking a random example) Suppose I am an insurer and I want to write a insurance policy for cars chaincode. Considering the architecture, would I deploy a new chaincode for every car insurance I sell? or would one deployment of my chaincode handle all insurances of the same type?

pd93
2016-12-06 16:01
@synblockchainteam People here are pretty good at answering questions, although searching slack/stackoverflow/google may find you an answer first. Also note that this channel is specifically for chaincode, not "hyperledger v0.6" in general. What do you want to know?

pd93
2016-12-06 16:02
@donjohnny You'd write your chaincode and deploy it once and then 'invoke' it each time you'd like to create a new policy through an SDK or REST call.

donjohnny
2016-12-06 16:04
@pd93 sounds fair enough, so that's what I would use the tables for I assume? Can I also store more complex datastructures? Like different fields with values for every 'contract' ?

pd93
2016-12-06 16:08
Yes, the tables/states are where you store your data on the blockchain. You can make the table structure as complex as you like as far as I know.

pd93
2016-12-06 16:09
It's worth looking at IBM's learn-chaincode git https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode

pd93
2016-12-06 16:10
Also, this documentation has helped me a lot in developing my chaincode as it provides all the functions available in the shim package https://godoc.org/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim

@pschnap i am also stuck at the same issue !

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:32
oops .. `CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev`

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:32
@kansi I'm looking at the end-to-end docs that muralisr just linked me to: https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/10242/simple_test_with_skeletal_peer.md

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:33
not `PEER_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev`

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:33
ah, let me try that

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:33
that worked!

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:33
not that the end-to-end is not for “—peer-chaincodedev"

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:33
that mode has a gotcha

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:34
after successful endorsement the chaincode is deregistered by the endorser pending later commit

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:34
in non dev mode, the chaincode wil be broight up when you do an invoke

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:35
but in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode, after successful commit you’ll have to kill the chaincode and restart it

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:36
will likely be fixed at some point that `—peer-chaincodedev` mode does the right thing for dev mode (basically not deregister but let it stay)

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:36
weird

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:36
for now you have kill/restart chaincode

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:36
so i have to invoke the deploy, then kill the chaincode, then restart it

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:36
yea

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:36
and invoke/query will work

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:37
that is odd

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:38
I'll give it a shot; thank you very much for your help!

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:38
anytime

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:38
do try without —peer-chaincodedev mode too

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:39
I will -- I have to give it the path for the deploy command then too, correct?

kansi
2016-12-06 18:39

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:43
@pschnap yes in non-dev, you have to provide path

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:43

kansi
2016-12-06 18:44

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:45
yeah, that's what I was getting before muralisr pointed me to the orderer

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:45
do:

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:45
`fabric$ cd orderer`

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:45
`orderer$ go build`

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:45
`orderer$ ./orderer`

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:46
then start the peer and you shouldn't have those grpc errors (though I did have another one)

kansi
2016-12-06 18:47
i think this is what you are seeing `18:46:53.651 [committer] readUntilClose -> ERRO 06b Invalid transaction, error Invalid creator specified in the header`

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:48
yup

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:49
worked for me after that (even with that Invalid transaction error)

kansi
2016-12-06 18:49
hmmm ... let me also check !

kansi
2016-12-06 18:54
@pschnap work for me too :smile: ... finally !

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:54
awesome!

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:55
@pschnap @kansi just FYI, if u kill orderer first, you cannot Ctrl-C on peer (you have to do a kill -9 <peer’s pid>) … there’s CR out there that’ll fix it

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:56
but if you kill peer first, ctrl-c will work

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:56
thanks muralisr

pschnap
2016-12-06 18:56
and thanks again for all your help!

kansi
2016-12-06 18:57
@muralisr i am using `peer node stop` to stop the peer

muralisr
2016-12-06 18:57
not tried that with master honestly

pschnap
2016-12-06 19:01
it seems I have to specify a name when specifying a path still? I though the name would be assigned automatically and returned

kansi
2016-12-06 19:03
yup

muralisr
2016-12-06 19:11
@pschnap the automatic assignment is gone in 1.0 … the name you specify is the unique one used by fabric

muralisr
2016-12-06 19:12
long story short … as we have the luxury of “life cycle system chaincode” we can do these things

kansi
2016-12-06 19:13

muralisr
2016-12-06 19:20
the orderers default configuration is to wait 10 seconds to batch up all transactions to order

muralisr
2016-12-06 19:20
typically I wait to see the “Commit” message on the peer console before I send querie

kansi
2016-12-06 19:33

kansi

kansi

2016-12-07 07:28

iamsamwood
2016-12-07 07:33
has joined #chaincode

vdods
2016-12-07 07:34
The preferred protocol is now GRPC, which is good because it seems like far superior to REST, where you'd have to serialize/deserialize the API calls yourself

vdods
2016-12-07 07:34
v0.6 and v1.0 both can use GRPC, so it seems like a no-lose situation going with GRPC

iamsamwood
2016-12-07 07:38
@vdods I thought v0.6 only supported json RPC? did a minor version bring that in ?

vdods
2016-12-07 07:40
As far as I can tell, HFC interacts with the membersrvc, peer, and event hub entirely via GRPC

vdods
2016-12-07 07:40
v0.6

2016-12-07 09:01

In this case, we are not getting the "hash" of chain code that we could use in "invoke" & "query" methods. Please let us know, if we need to make CHANGES in core.yaml or membersrvc.yaml to get "HASH" in the the response message from "deploy" method of hyperledger v 0.6. Thanks

garisingh
2016-12-07 10:38
@synblockchainteam - seems like you might be running in chaincode development mode? In that case, you use NAME to deploy and you can then also use that same NAME as the chaincode ID when performing invokes or queries

2016-12-08 16:54

muralisr
2016-12-08 16:54
@plucena are you running in dev mode ?

plucena
2016-12-08 16:54
Hi @muralisr yes

bfuentes
2016-12-08 16:55
I advise you guyz to use official Docker images V0.6.1

bfuentes
2016-12-08 16:55
more stable

bfuentes
2016-12-08 16:55
https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-peer/tags/

plucena
2016-12-08 16:56
Yes, I have created a separate environment based on 0.6.1 I will test now

muralisr
2016-12-08 16:56
so, like we said, once you “deploy “ the chaincode in dev mode, the peer deregisters it like it would any other chaincode

muralisr
2016-12-08 16:56
after you see a successful “commit” on the peer logs, you just have to kill and restart the chaincode

plucena
2016-12-08 16:56
Hmmm

kansi
2016-12-08 16:56
^ yup

muralisr
2016-12-08 16:56
and you should be able to use query and invoke

plucena
2016-12-08 16:57
Should I kill it after peer deploy?

kansi
2016-12-08 16:57
no

kansi
2016-12-08 16:57
just restart the chaincode

muralisr
2016-12-08 16:57
so here’ the sequence

muralisr
2016-12-08 16:59
``` CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode deploy … … wait for “Commit “ message on the peer’s console ctrl-c the chaincode and restart it CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode invoke … CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode query …```

kansi
2016-12-08 17:00
@muralisr btw thanks for your help on this one

plucena
2016-12-08 17:01
:+1:

muralisr
2016-12-08 17:01
also, when you want to start afresh,

muralisr
2016-12-08 17:02
``` kill the peer, kill the orderer rm -rf /var/hyperledger/* start the orderer start the peer resume tests```

muralisr
2016-12-08 17:04
Its great you are all trying on 1.0 code base, it really is… its work in progress and likely flaky but this helps to make this better. really appreciate it

muralisr
2016-12-08 20:08

donjohnny
2016-12-11 11:09
Hello all, can Invoke return a message to the client? I'm returning errors but the rest reply is always OK

muralisr
2016-12-11 13:39
@donjohnny in 0.6 and other non-master releases, only the Query directly returns. Invoke and deploy are just “submits” which return a transaction id (a reciept) for the submission

donjohnny
2016-12-11 13:44
@muralisr does the master release support the return in invoke and deploy?

cbf
2016-12-11 13:44
no they are asynch

muralisr
2016-12-11 13:47
right at some level they are, but for the SDK and end user, it does return a result directly (as opposed to 0.5)

cbf
2016-12-11 13:48
@muralisr corrected me off line... invoke is synchrounous in v1.0 - I need to brush up on all the changes since my vacation and extended travels

donjohnny
2016-12-11 13:50

2016-12-11 16:12
@donjohnny I am working on the docs now. We haven't yet published any images, you would need to build them locally for testing

2016-12-12 06:43

ruslan
2016-12-12 07:23
Docs for v0.7?

ruslan
2016-12-12 08:10
Hello guys, I’ve found out that rest api had been removed from fabric v0.7. How can I invoke commands?

bfuentes
2016-12-12 09:36
@ruslan => GRPC

ruslan
2016-12-12 09:52
Okay. It is my understanding that chaincode can be deployed from git repository only?

ruslan
2016-12-12 09:53
with production-mode

ruslan
2016-12-12 09:53
(without —peer-chaincodedev)

bfuentes
2016-12-12 10:26
@ruslan with GO CC you can use local path visible from the peer

garisingh
2016-12-12 10:27
@ruslan - no - with the REST API if you wanted to deploy remote chaincode (i.e. chaincode that was not in the local GOPATH for the peer) then yes - your code had to be available in a public git repository. If you use the NodeJS SDK, then your chaincode needs to be local to the machine where you are running your SDK-based app so it can package it up and send it over to the peer.

shinji
2016-12-12 14:13
@shinji uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/shinji/F3CTPEJ0Z/-.txt

shinji
2016-12-12 14:13

pschnap
2016-12-12 16:26
I was getting help the other week and someone mentioned that with the current master, *when working in development mode*, you have to restart your chaincode after you do the deploy command before you can start invoking on it

pschnap
2016-12-12 16:26
@shinji ^

pschnap
2016-12-12 16:26
in short: start chaincode, run deploy, stop chaincode, restart chaincode, start invoking

pschnap
2016-12-12 16:26
but only when running in dev mode, it's not necessary when not running in dev mode

mdevilliers
2016-12-12 17:01
What is the best way to debug ```2016-12-12 16:58:26.711 UTC [chaincode] processStream -> ERRO 202 Error handling chaincode support stream: stream error: code = 1 desc = "context canceled"``` ?

mdevilliers
2016-12-12 17:01
Output from `peer node` whist deploying ( from master branch)

mdevilliers
2016-12-12 17:03
The deploy looks to be progressing well then I assume it encounters an error - just not too sure what the error could be?

silliman
2016-12-12 17:05
@mdevilliers This message is okay per the last link here https://wiki.hyperledger.org/community/fabric-design-docs (specifically, in the 'v1 end-to-end skeleton instructions' where it explains that this message is OK to ignore, and why)

mdevilliers
2016-12-12 19:21
@silliman thanks - looking at the doc does say this is expected - my mistake must be some where else. Thanks again

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:03
has joined #chaincode

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:09
@abhishekseth uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/abhishekseth/F3FSK5P55/screen_shot_2016-12-15_at_3.46.04_pm.png and commented: hey all, I am using fabric v0.6. Further, I am using NodeSDK to deploy, invoke and query my chaincodes. In DEV-mode, everything is working fine, but in NON-DEV mode, it is giving me deployment time error. Here is the snippet of the error:

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:11
Any help is highly appreciated…. @garisingh , @ghaskins , @muralisr

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:20
@abhishekseth I _think_ the problem is that in v0.6, you need to explicitly vendor your deps (which includes the shim)

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:20
@garisingh is probably a better resource to ask, though

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:21
in my chaincode folder, I have vendor as well but that does not have shim. But i think vendor is only for 3 PPs, right?

bazmcl
2016-12-15 12:23
has joined #chaincode

garisingh
2016-12-15 12:24
@abhishekseth - as @ghaskins said, it v0.6 you actually have to vendor the fabric src code as well when deploying chaincode via any of the SDKs

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:28
ohh..

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:28
it is not the case with REST api, right?

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:31
@abhishekseth the REST api has its own bundling engine that runs in the context of the peer you sent the directive to

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:31
so I think both the potential variance in NVP vs SDK plus the variance in the context in which they run may impact whether the shim gets bundled

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:32
this is all going to get cleaned up, and is already better in master

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:32
but v0.6 might be a little rough around the edges in this regad

ghaskins
2016-12-15 12:32
regard

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:38
ohhkk…. i will try that.

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 12:38
Thanks a lot for the help

abhishekseth
2016-12-15 13:38
@garisingh... that is working. Thanks a lot again

thojest
2016-12-15 17:05
has joined #chaincode

thojest
2016-12-15 17:05
hello all together

thojest
2016-12-15 17:06
i have just made my first chaincode tutorial

thojest
2016-12-15 17:07
is it correct that every function in the chaincode is somehow mapped to the public functions Init, Invoke and Query ?

thojest
2016-12-15 17:07
so that fabric knows if it is only a query or it has to write something into the blockchain?

mheitz
2016-12-15 21:33
has joined #chaincode

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:19
@thojest I would describe it as the other way around

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:20
all functions tunnel through either Init, Invoke, or Query

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:20
(though generally, theres always only one init

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:20
at least, that is how it is when you use the raw chaincode interface

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:21
if you use something like chaintool, the tunneling is transparent

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:28
but otherwise, yes, you are correct

ghaskins
2016-12-15 23:28
the system can optimize query types to bypass consensus, and it will also prohibit mutations to ledger state

thojest
2016-12-16 10:01
is there a more elegant way when writing chaincode for the tunneling than using if statements?

thojest
2016-12-16 10:02
what I mean is, when you have several functions which tunnel through Invoke you always have to check which function is called by using an if statement in Invoke

pd93
2016-12-16 11:04
@thojest Use a switch statement?

pd93
2016-12-16 11:12
Only thing I could find as an alternative is this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8103617/call-a-struct-and-its-method-by-name-in-go Personally I'd prefer to stick to the explicit list.

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:34
@thojest you can use a map

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:34
or, you can just use chaintool and I'll write the map for you :wink:

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:38
actually, I just looked...it looks like the current version of chaintool uses both a map and a switch statement

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:38
but this could have been all maps, or all switches, etc...its up to you

ghaskins
2016-12-16 13:40
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3GDHGSB0/-.m and commented: @thojest something like this

utkucan
2016-12-16 15:56
has joined #chaincode

umasuthan
2016-12-16 16:20
@ghaskins, Thanks so much for the code sample. This is much neater than the if statements. Does V 0.6 support this kind of tunnelling? I guess it should. Please correct me.

ghaskins
2016-12-16 16:23
Yes, that is from v0.6 code

umasuthan
2016-12-16 16:29
Thank you.

2016-12-20 10:36
Hi There, GetRows of shim code works fine when multiple rows returned. If there is a single row expecting to be returned using GetRows, it is returning empty. Any idea why? I'm using : rowChannel, err := stub.GetRows(tableName, columns) if err != nil { return nil, fmt.Errorf("Failed retriving details : [%s]", err) } var rows []shim.Row for { select { case temprow, ok := <-rowChannel: if !ok { rowChannel = nil } else { rows = append(rows, temprow) } } if rowChannel == nil { break } } return rows, nil

2016-12-21 06:45

umasuthan
2016-12-21 06:47
is it a must that I need to have the chaincode file in the root directory of the repository?

name63
2016-12-21 06:47
this path parameter is actual directory path to your chaincode on the peer host.

name63
2016-12-21 06:48
which means that full path that fabric will use will be "$GOPATH/github.com/umasuthanramakrishnan/ibm/itops/chaincode"

name63
2016-12-21 06:49
correct me if i'm wrong, but peer can't download from github, can he?

umasuthan
2016-12-21 06:50

name63
2016-12-21 06:53

name63
2016-12-21 06:54

synblockchainteam
2016-12-21 07:07
@umasuthan , Please make sure that your main contract is in chaincode folder

umasuthan
2016-12-21 07:24

vigneswaran.r
2016-12-21 08:48
@umasuthan As @name63 suggested, copy the chaincode into the peer node. You can use "docker cp" command to copy the chaincode from host to the peer docker container.

umasuthan
2016-12-21 08:57
@vigneswaran.r, Sure. I will try that.

pd93
2016-12-21 09:34
@pd93 uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/pd93/F3GNRCH40/Mounting_volumes_using_docker-compose.yaml and commented: @umasuthan Just for future reference. You can also mount a directory from your host machine onto your docker container by putting something like this in your docker-compose.yml. This is what I do to deploy my chaincode. It means I never need to transfer anything because the chaincode is always up to date.

umasuthan
2016-12-21 10:00
@pd93, I was also thinking of volumes. Thanks for the reference.

umasuthan
2016-12-21 12:16
Ok. I did a bit more work on this. I tried to deploy the chaincode on Bluemix and ran into same error I was getting on my docker environment. Later, I dumped all the Go code into a single file and fried to deploy on Bluemix and I was able to deploy. Next, I will planning to try this on docker environment. I will experiment both single Go file option from github and multiple files with volumes. The volumes option should work as others have done it successfully. Now, I need to also find out to to have the chaincode split into multiple packages/files and get them deployed on Bluemix I will post my findings once I am done.

haixu
2016-12-22 09:57

cbf
2016-12-22 12:57
@vigneswaran.r no, but as we continue past v1.0 we may seek to improve the resource consumption model.

bfuentes
2016-12-22 14:27
@vigneswaran.r you can only destroy the container manually and not do more calls with its chaincodeID

joeb
2017-01-04 14:51
has joined #chaincode

thojest
2017-01-04 15:04
hey guys i dont quite understand what exactly `CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./gochaincode` does

thojest
2017-01-04 15:05
deploying is clear to me, but what exactly am i doing with this line

thojest
2017-01-04 15:05
isnt it basically starting a go programme with parameters?

cbf
2017-01-04 15:49
@thojest this is a developer mode of operation that runs the chaincode natively (as opposed to having the peer launch a Docker image of your chaincode) thus allowing you to do things such as attach a debugger etc.

thojest
2017-01-04 16:00
@cbf i thought this would do running `peer node start --peer-chaincodedev`

thojest
2017-01-04 16:03
i thought `CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./gochaincode` would have something to do with registering the chaincode

thojest
2017-01-04 16:03
what ever that means :smile:

thojest
2017-01-04 16:04
would you be so kind and help me with my confusion

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:27
@thojest copying instructions for running in `—peer-chaincodedev` mode in 1.0… (still a bit of WIP but this should work)

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:27
```Will use the CLI/Vagrant env for these steps to run in --peer-chaincodedev mode in 1.0 Vagrant window 1 - build peer make peer Vagrant window 2 - start orderer cd orderer go build ./orderer Vagrant window 2 - start peer in dev mode cd peer peer node start --peer-chaincodedev Vagrant window 3 - start chaincode example02 in dev mode cd examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02 go build CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=127.0.0.1:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc ./chaincode_example02 Vagrant window 4 - initialize the chaincode using the "deploy" command cd peer CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Args":["init","a","100","b","200"]}' CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev is needed in 1.0 with chaincode deploy. Unlike 0.6/0.7, 1.0 builds the chaincode in the deploy command. CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev is needed to tell the deploy command not to skip build related activities #wait for about 10seconds #kill Ctrl-C chaincode_example02 and start chaincode_example02 again in Vagrant window 3. #This is needed - for now - as the fabric deregisters the chaincode after deploy Vagrant window 3 - restart chaincode Ctrl-C running chaincode CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=127.0.0.1:7051 CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc ./chaincode_example02 #now you can send invokes and queries as usual from window 4 Vagrant window 4 - send an invoke cd peer CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev peer chaincode invoke -n mycc -c '{"Args":["invoke","a","b","10"]}’```

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:28
^^^ above does not address running from SDK but hopefully has enough details to help you with that as well (basically how do you set the equivalent of CORE_CHAINCODE_MODE=dev in the SDK when doing deploy)

thojest
2017-01-04 16:29
@muralisr thx a lot but im not using vagrant and i can already run a peer node in dev mode. my questions aimed at a better understanding of what i am actually doing

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:31
understood. my goal was to make sure you can run in dev mode first in 1.0

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:31
if you have already done that, great!

thojest
2017-01-04 16:31
yeah thx for that. im using v.06

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:31
ah nm then

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:31
sorry about that

thojest
2017-01-04 16:31
so my main question is: before deploying a chaincode

thojest
2017-01-04 16:32
im running this cmdline `CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./gochaincode` what exactly is it doing

thojest
2017-01-04 16:32
@cbf already answered but i dont get the point

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:32
in dev mode, it is connecting to the peer and registering with it

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:32
the “init” method has not been called to initialze the chaincode

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:33
which has to be done via the “deploy” command

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:33
in dev mode “deploy” will skip the actualy deploying of the chaincode (because you have already done that by starting and registering) and will just do the init part

thojest
2017-01-04 16:33
@muralisr when the peer is not running in dev mode what command would i have to enter then to register the chaincode

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:34
no

thojest
2017-01-04 16:34
ahhhh

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:34
when not running in dev mode, the peer would start the CC and registration happens without your involvement

thojest
2017-01-04 16:35
i think i get it now

muralisr
2017-01-04 16:36
@thojest ..have to be away for a bit but will be online later if you have more qs

thojest
2017-01-04 16:36
@muralisr thx a lot this helped me to get a better picture

thojest
2017-01-04 16:37
so when NOT being in dev mode this cmdline `CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./gochaincode` is obsolete because i do that when deploying the chaincode?

thojest
2017-01-04 16:40
using the -p flag and pointing to the compiled gocode

cbf
2017-01-04 16:41
yes

cbf
2017-01-04 16:41
basically, the command is only to test your chaincode

thojest
2017-01-04 16:41
@cbf @muralisr very nice thx for the input

cbf
2017-01-04 16:41
when operating normally, you would deploy the chaincode via the SDK and the peer node would be responsible for spinning it up in a Docker container

thojest
2017-01-04 16:42
@cbf thx for clarification. btw do you know an answer for my question in the fabric channel?

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:07
Can anyone help?

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:16
Hi, Have you tried using one of the demo chaincode deployments from within the blockchain service dashboard? How are you trying to deploy (REST or HFC)? Which tutorial are you trying to deploy?

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:22
@dgorman I've tried the demos, and various other things...nothing seems to work :sweat:

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:22
I'm trying to deploy via the swagger api on the bluemix dashboard, so presumably this is REST

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:30
Yes that does use REST. Did you create the blockchain service a while ago? There is a retention policy in place now. V1.0.0 of the blockchain service added “Dormant networks will be removed after 15 days of inactivity”.

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:31
The blockchain was created this morning.

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:31
This is the response I'm getting via the swagger API

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:31
{ "jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": { "code": -32001, "message": "Deployment failure", "data": "Error when deploying chaincode: Error getting chaincode package bytes: Error getting code 'go get' failed with error: \"exit status 1\"\npackage http://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/tree/v2.0/finished: cannot find package \"http://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/tree/v2.0/finished\" in any of:\n\t/opt/go/src/github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/tree/v2.0/finished (from $GOROOT)\n\t/opt/gopath/_usercode_/237815087/src/github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/tree/v2.0/finished (from $GOPATH)\n\t/opt/gopath/src/github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/tree/v2.0/finished\n" }, "id": 1 }

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:34
ok, what does your REST message look like?

series0ne
2017-01-04 17:35
{ "jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "deploy", "params": { "type": 1, "chaincodeID": { "path": "https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/tree/v2.0/finished" }, "ctorMsg": { "function": "init", "args": ["HELLO, WORLD"] }, "secureContext": "user_type1_0" }, "id": 1 }

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:36
ok, let me try too, be a couple of mins

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:38
I get the same error message, let me see if I can figure out what is wrong, 1 min

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:40
try changing the chaincode path to http://gopkg.in/ibm-blockchain/learn-chaincode.v2/finished

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:40
that worked for me

dgorman
2017-01-04 17:41
the readme says to use the gopkg path rather than github: https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/learn-chaincode/blob/master/README.md

2017-01-05 13:33

bfuentes
2017-01-05 13:33
the is the cleanest way to do it

bfuentes
2017-01-05 13:33

bfuentes

satheesh

wangmzdl
2017-01-11 08:51
has joined #chaincode

wangmzdl
2017-01-11 08:52
I was thinking Chaincode has be deployed on Peer Node, seems I'm wrong

wangmzdl
2017-01-11 08:52
Peers won't work if ChainCode container is shutdown, correct?

yevot
2017-01-11 08:55
@wangmzdl As far as I understand it, chaincode is how you modify the world state, but the world state and the blockchain still exist on the peer even when it's not running.

yevot
2017-01-11 08:56
If you start the peer, start the chaincode, do some transactions, and then stop the chaincode, you will still be able to view the blockchain from the peer.

yevot
2017-01-11 08:56
However, you won't be able to make queries against the world state because those go through chaincode to process.

yevot
2017-01-11 08:57
Without the chaincode you'll still be able to see blocks and transactions.

yevot
2017-01-11 08:57
At least that's been my experience with v0.6

wangmzdl
2017-01-11 08:57
thanks @yevot

yevot
2017-01-11 08:58
Sure

wangmzdl
2017-01-11 08:59
could Chaincode be saved on peer? sync between peers? running on peers?

yevot
2017-01-11 09:01
each peer should be executing the chaincode, i think

yevot
2017-01-11 09:01
I believe transactions should be sent to one peer and then distributed out to all the peers to compute. That way they can confirm a valid transaction, update their world state, and reach consensus on the hash of the result

yevot
2017-01-11 09:03
I turned off chaincode and the peer is still handing out information about the blockchain if I go to http://172.17.0.1:7050/chain/ via the host.

rachweb2
2017-01-11 13:49
has joined #chaincode

ruslan
2017-01-12 08:42

ruslan
2017-01-12 08:43

marvsperez
2017-01-12 10:48
has joined #chaincode

erickan
2017-01-12 12:25
has joined #chaincode

arnaud
2017-01-12 12:39
@ruslan I believe this is actually all you can do at this time - with v0.6

arnaud
2017-01-12 12:40
this is because the ledger is a simple key/value pair database and the table stuff is merely a thin layer/hack on top with limited capabilities

arnaud
2017-01-12 12:42
in 1.0 you will have the possibility of setting up couchDB as the ledger for better query capabilities

marvsperez
2017-01-12 13:24

zemtsov
2017-01-12 13:30
try `car-lease-demo` or `marbles`. there is an node.js app which work with blockchain and chaincode via HFC

zemtsov
2017-01-12 13:30
https://github.com/ibm-blockchain/car-lease-demo

zemtsov
2017-01-12 13:30
https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/marbles

marvsperez
2017-01-12 13:31
thanks @zemtsov , will check on that.

silliman
2017-01-12 16:02
@marvsperez FYI, marbles uses an older npm package called *ibm-blockchain-js* that will not be maintained going forward whereas car-lease-demo uses the HFC which is strategic. So while marbles is a nice demo with a clean, simple GUI, and has its merits, if you are studying the app code to see how it interacts with fabric, your time will be better served looking at the car-lease-demo.

dsanchezseco
2017-01-17 16:24

dsanchezseco
2017-01-17 16:25
i'm trying to use the tables and i have defined one like this ```func (t *tableHandler) createTable(stub shim.ChaincodeStubInterface) error { // Create identity table return stub.CreateTable(tableName, []*shim.ColumnDefinition{ &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: columnEcert, Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_BYTES, Key: true}, &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: columnName, Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_STRING, Key: false}, &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: columnSurname, Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_STRING, Key: false}, &shim.ColumnDefinition{Name: columnBirthDate, Type: shim.ColumnDefinition_STRING, Key: false}, }) } func (t *tableHandler) insertRow(stub shim.ChaincodeStubInterface, key []byte, name, surname, birthDate string) error { ok, err := stub.InsertRow(tableName, shim.Row{ Columns: []*shim.Column{ &shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_Bytes{Bytes: key}}, &shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_String_{String_: name}}, &shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_String_{String_: surname}}, &shim.Column{Value: &shim.Column_String_{String_: birthDate}}, }}) // you can only assign balances to new account IDs if !ok && err == nil { fmt.Errorf("system error %v", err) return errors.New( strconv.FormatBool(ok) + " Identity already exists!") } return nil }``` but when i try to insert it always returns false(key already exists) but the contract is empty and y change the key every time. Any clue?

alanlee
2017-01-21 01:04
Question: Dear, Do we have Audit Trail/History of Variables Values for all the INVOKE in ChainCode?: In bitcoin, all valid transaction (e.g. user A=> user B (5 BTC), user B=>user C (3 BTC)) will be recorded in the Bitcoin Block. This provides an audit trail feature. Do we have any audit trail record for variables changed in ChainCode ? If no, we cannot find out the history of the variable. Thank you.

silliman
2017-01-21 02:27
Hello @alanlee this is in the works for Fabric v1.0 see Jira 1502 https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1502

alanlee
2017-01-21 02:50
Thanks @silliman . So, I need to upgrade to use Fabric v1.0 to enjoy this feature (variable history). Seems quite different between v1.0 and v0.6.

garisingh
2017-01-21 12:59
@andrew_tharp - it won't work. I'm also pretty sure that we've never tried using Java chaincode with the BMX services. There's a few PRs on Fabric around adding TLS support to Java chaincode but they have not been merged last I checked

silliman
2017-01-21 14:00
@alanlee in v0.6 you'd have to write the logic yourself, e.g. store the value of a key as an array that keeps history, but I doubt it's worth your while. The underlying architecture of v1.0 is a for all intents and purposes a rewrite of v0.6 but the difficulty required to migrate v0.6-compatible chaincode to v1.0-compatible chaincode is being advertised as minimal.

arner
2017-01-21 15:32
When upgrading a chaincode in v1, is the world state kept intact?

garisingh
2017-01-22 11:21
@arner - yes - chaincode is accessed by name so when you do an update the state will be associated with the new instance of the chaincode and it will be transparent to your apps

alanlee
2017-01-23 02:47
Thanks @silliman

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:29
@ghaskins uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3V5KKZNY/-.c and commented: @muralisr @grapebaba regarding above: working on a patch that splits the Platform responsibilities like this

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:29
The idea being that what was formerly "WritePackage()" is now two phases

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:30
for something like golang/java, the deployment payload would be near identical to what it is today, sans the Dockerfile

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:31
for car, it would no longer be a car encapsulated in a .tgz with Dockerfile, but just the raw .car data

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:31
and lastly, GenerateDockerBuild() will JIT it into a .tgz complete with Dockerfile that may be sent to the docker daemon to be built

grapebaba
2017-01-23 13:36
Yes, I also thought about that platform interface could be extend.

grapebaba
2017-01-23 13:36
So do you mean you are working on that?

grapebaba
2017-01-23 13:52
@ghaskins: @muralisr since you guys are refactoring this area, i will abandon this CR

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:52
@grapebaba yes, but not with the same goals you had

grapebaba
2017-01-23 13:54
Will be back to see again when you guys tasks done

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:54
ok

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:55
theres probably still room for your type of improvement

ghaskins
2017-01-23 13:56
havent decided if Ill try to tackle or defer, but it probably does make sense to coordinate so we dont stomp on each others work

nikeshgogia

nikeshgogia
2017-01-26 09:32

ikruiper
2017-01-26 09:33
hey @thojest : it is true that in v0.6, the error that you might expect from the invoke method signature will effectively not be populated...it is a known limitation that is being addressed in v1.0...it is also true with the actual byte[] returned by the invoke method...it won't work either: You will just get the transaction hash, regardless of it being actually fully validated/committed to the chain. If you do want to get going and can't wait for v1.0, I would suggest leveraging the Event (SetEvent method) and using the EventHub within hfc to consume potential outcomes of the invoke (being success or failure)...it is not ideal, but that's possibly one way for you to do what you are trying to do...I guess

thojest
2017-01-26 10:04
hey @ikruiper thx alot. thats what i expected. but thanks for the answer

thojest
2017-01-26 10:04
i think it would also be possible to call a query after certain invokes to somehow fake an invoke return

2017-01-26 16:57

muralisr
2017-01-26 16:57
