muralisr
2017-01-26 17:08
also @arnaud one other thing struck me

muralisr
2017-01-26 17:08
you would want to preface `CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig` to peer and CLI commands

muralisr
2017-01-26 17:09
so `CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer node start —peer-defaultchain=false`

muralisr
2017-01-26 17:09
and

muralisr
2017-01-26 17:09
`CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer chaincode deploy ….`

arnaud
2017-01-26 17:49
Ok, thanks, I will look into that but joining the channel failed after that...

arnaud
2017-01-26 17:50
I didn't get the expected 200 response. I got no response code...

muralisr
2017-01-26 17:52
```CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer channel create -c myc CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer node start --peer-defaultchain=false CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer channel join -b myc.block CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -C myc -p http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02 -c '{"Args":["init","a","100","b","200"]}' CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sampleconfig peer chaincode query -n mycc -C myc -c '{"Args":["query","a"]}’``` my little cheat sheet @arnaud

mgutala
2017-01-26 18:04
Can I do the network deployment of chaincodes in fabric 1.0 ?

muralisr
2017-01-26 18:15
@mgutala 0.6 relied on fabric to get the chaincode and deploy. In 1.0 the packaging is done in CLI and SDK (and @ghaskins was working on refining it even further I think…) which are not “peer” processes. so in a sense deployment is external already… now, can the CLI or SDK go out to network and get the chaincode before packaging ? They probably can… that path in CLI is there (the `peer chaincode deploy -p https://...` path) but I think is broken.

muralisr
2017-01-26 18:15
(not sure if that answers the question… :slightly_smiling_face: )

arnaud
2017-01-26 18:20
Thanks @muralisr!

kletkeman
2017-01-26 18:22
WOW ... I sure hope that the fairly recent change in the return signatures for Init and Invoke to "pb.Response" has bought us some seriously impressive features, because I have some pretty extensive refactoring ahead of me.

arnaud
2017-01-26 18:23
Why do you specify CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH on every command rather setting it once and for all in your env if it's always the same?

iamsamwood
2017-01-26 18:24
hello, I was hoping that someone could provide clarification regarding non-determinism described here (https://console.ng.bluemix.net/docs/services/blockchain/nondeterministic.html). Specifically, this sentence "For example, do not run any query transactions in parallel with invoke transactions, because parallel queries could produce variance in the invocation values across nodes.” Does this mean a client should not issue concurrent queries and invokes ?

kletkeman
2017-01-26 18:26
@iamsamwood You have to take into account the fact that the query will see only committed blocks, so if you tun queries against commits that are in progress, you will randomly get the before state or the after state, depending on race conditions and other timing issues. If you want the queries to be deterministic, you will want to ensure that a transaction is completed and committed before looking for its results.

iamsamwood
2017-01-26 18:27
@kletkeman thank you. So your app that uses the client might be non-deterministic, but this wouldn’t trigger non-determinism within the chain code and a failure in consensus, correct?

kletkeman
2017-01-26 18:28
if you write chaincode that depends on the results of a query to another chaincode, you can be burnt by timing issues and have each peer get a differing result. That will cause endorsers to return differing r/w sets and thus will fail consensus.

kletkeman
2017-01-26 18:29
you need to know that the data is stable before depending on it

iamsamwood
2017-01-26 18:30
OK. In this case, the chaincode does not call any other chaincode, but a client off chain issues concurrent queries and invokes. That wouldn’t trigger consensus failure in the chaincode per se, would it? Thanks again @kletkeman

muralisr
2017-01-26 18:32
@arnaud `Why do you specify CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH on every command rather setting it once and for all in your env if it's always the same?` working on that

muralisr
2017-01-26 18:33
^^^ trying to wean away from “sampleconfig” as the default now that bootstrap is progressing caused that inconvenience.

kletkeman
2017-01-26 18:33
No ... but it might create logically inconsistent data in world state. If you are running a state machine in the client and you depend on seeing everything in the right order, and if you don't watch for events that guarantee that the data is stable (i.e. you see a transaction in a block event) then you could end up thinking you are sending the latest state where you are actually sending the previous state again ...

arnaud
2017-01-26 18:33
@muralisr ok

rahulhegde
2017-01-26 19:36
@kletkeman - My understanding, this is coming from the MVCC mechanism used by Couch DB where a read-set getting constructed from multiple keys may not be from a single KV-Ledger snapshot if there is transaction commit getting processed by peer at the same time of query processing.

iamsamwood
2017-01-26 20:05
Thanks again @kletkeman . a related question I had is the ordering of transactions within a block—are they all applied in the same order across nodes?

kletkeman
2017-01-26 20:06
@iamsamwood Yes, the ordering service ensures that all blocks are identical.

iamsamwood
2017-01-26 20:06
and the transactions within an individual block are applied in the same order?

kletkeman
2017-01-26 20:07
@iamsamwood Yes. Identical does not have any other interpretation :slightly_smiling_face: ... the ordering service creates what amounts to the block structure and that is passed to all committers. To my knowledge.

kletkeman
2017-01-26 20:11
@rahulhegde Well, if the peers are not able to agree on the world state snapshot level for the transaction, then the results will vary and consensus will fail. On the other hand, the creation of the next block in a chain is not done in parallel with other blocks (subchains can be done in parallel but my understanding is that each chain is processed serially for this very reason.) So that means that the chaincode that happens to be executing should be seeing a consistent world state level. No other chaincode can interfere on one chain (and if they start allowing that then good luck with consensus :-))

kletkeman
2017-01-26 20:15
@rahulhegde I suppose that the r/w sets could be different if each endorser receives interleaved requests for the same asset keys from different clients. The state of each key will be different across peers. But assume that you can get the required number of endorsers to agree on a r/w set, then you override the others and the orderers ensure that block x+1 is identical across peers.

kletkeman
2017-01-26 20:16
A well-designed system is not likely to do a lot of the interleaved writes thing ...

youngbamboo
2017-01-26 21:17
has joined #chaincode

youngbamboo
2017-01-26 21:22
Hi guys, I have a question. I'm trying to play the chaincode example based on the instruction. After the command 'CORE_CHAINCODE_ID_NAME=mycc CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:7051 ./chaincode_example02', I opened a new terminal and run the command 'peer chaincode deploy -n mycc -c '{"Args": ["init", "a","100", "b", "200"]}''. There is error message said 'Error getting chaincode package bytes: Cannot generate hashcode from empty chaincode path'. I logged in the node by 'docker exec -it pbft_vp0_1 bash', there is no such file under /opt/gopath/src/github.com. Could you help?

youngbamboo
2017-01-26 21:22
Thanks.

kletkeman
2017-01-26 21:27
@youngbamboo Did you start your peer in chaincodedev mode? Because it does not try to fetch the chaincode in that mode. Looks like you are trying to debug against a normal peer ...

youngbamboo
2017-01-26 21:28
Oh I see. I will start in dev mode and try again. Thanks.

kletkeman
2017-01-26 21:28
cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric make peer peer node start --peer-chaincodedev

kletkeman
2017-01-26 21:28
Those are from the chaincode-setup doc ...

youngbamboo
2017-01-26 21:30
Cool. Thanks.

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 13:06
If a chaincode issues a `stub.DelState()` to delete an item (using the Go syntax) is the disk space storing that item eventually "freed" so that it may be reused later, either within the same chaincode or by other chaincode (e.g. by `stub.PutState()` for a different key)? In other terms, are deletes in chaincode logical deletions that mask a more permanent storage or does a delete actually end up freeing up storage in rocksdb?

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 13:10
I have been writing chaincode assuming that deletions are real and that by creating and deleting many keys I would not inadvertently use up my whole disk in a real world deployment scenario

garisingh
2017-01-28 13:12
@bmatsuo - yes - the statedb stores the latest values for each key. So if you delete a key, you are effectively deleting it from the database. Of course every transaction is persisted within blocks and blocks are not deleted

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 13:16
@garisingh: Thanks. I am aware that the transaction payload will be persisted, and that may cause some redundancy of what is stored on disk (block data vs app data).

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 13:19
But I might have a transaction that causes me to delete a set of keys, or move their payload under different keys or something, and from what you are saying I understand these types of operations would not affect my storage capabilities in a way I didn't expect. So thanks again :slightly_smiling_face:

garisingh
2017-01-28 13:21
of course we are at the mercy of how rocksdb optimizes storage, etc, but your assumptions are correct about deleting keys

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 13:23
Heh. Of course.

wangmzdl
2017-01-28 13:40
Happy New Year, Guys~

silliman
2017-01-28 16:16
@bmatsuo Rocksdb is hard-coded as the state database in Fabric v0.6, but it is out of the picture in Fabric 1.0 where the state data will use goLevelDB by default, with an optional CouchDB implemenation as well, and other databases can get involved as the state database is pluggable.

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 16:22
@silliman Wow. Interesting. Pluggable things are great :smile: What was the issue with Rocksdb? I thought it was supposed to be a better LevelDB?

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 16:23
I happen to maintain http://github.com/bmatsuo/lmdb-go, so I am always interested in things with pluggable backend storage interfaces :slightly_smiling_face:

silliman
2017-01-28 16:24
@bmatsuo I don't know the details, and this is just conjecture, but I suspect the reasons may have been more political or license issue oriented, than technical. But I'll happily stand corrected if I'm wrong about this

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 16:25
Gotcha. I would love some clarification if anyone knows. But it's just a curiosity and not that important.

harrijk
2017-01-28 16:37
has joined #chaincode

silliman
2017-01-28 16:40
@bmatsuo I just received confirmation from an anonymous source, who may or may not bear any resemblance to the gentleman who just joined #chaincode at 11:37 AM, that my theory has merit- the switch was done primarily for legal or licensing issues.

karkal72
2017-01-28 17:00
has joined #chaincode

bmatsuo
2017-01-28 17:02
Thanks again @silliman, and mystery source :wink:

silliman
2017-01-28 17:05
@bmatsuo I won't divulge my source, but if you spot him in person, he's the one wearing the tee-shirt that says "Federal Witness Protection Program member".

silliman
2017-01-28 18:50
@bmatsuo check out the powerpoint in FAB-758, it is a thing of beauty, it discusses some of the database stuff we were chatting about, and much more. https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-758

bmatsuo
2017-01-30 09:02
Do state updates in chaincode (e.g. data passed to stub.PutState) get compressed on disk in any way? Put another way, if my chaincode compresses its own data will it benefit by being able to store more data?

bmatsuo
2017-01-30 09:04
Leaving compression up to the application seems like it would present problems in terms of determinism, especially where peers are deployed on heterogeneous platforms (e.g. some x86_64 peers and some ARM peers).

wlahti
2017-01-30 16:26

balakrishna
2017-02-02 06:38
@matanyahu if you want to use CLI command CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED=true CORE_SECURITY_PRIVACY=true peer chaincode invoke -u alice -l golang -n mycc -c '{"Function": "invoke", "Args": ["a", "b", "100"]}'

balakrishna
